The Marketing Team uses Sanity to manage content on stackoverflow.co. We also use it for creating things like The Overflow newsletter and the Policies site.

The CMS is accessible through Okta at cms.stackoverflow.co, built from StackEng/MarketingCMS and hosted through Netlify.

From their website:

Sanity.io is the platform for structured content. With Sanity.io you can manage your text, images, and other media with APIs. You can also use the open-source single page application Sanity Studio to quickly set up an editing environment that you can customize. With Sanity.io you have access to a bunch of APIs, libraries, and tooling that helps you leverage the benefits of having all your content available as a single source of truth. This article will quickly walk you through some central concepts, giving you a head start.

  • Sanity.io has a real-time datastore for structured content, and supporting APIs for assets, user management, and more.
  • Sanity Studio is a user interface for managing content. It's an open-source React Single Page Application that you can customize and host wherever you want.
  • There are also SDKs, libraries, and tools that let you query your content and integrate it with websites, services, and other applications; wherever you need content.

Sanity API could be useful for a variety of needs (it works with .NET, Svelte etc) You can reach out to Brand Design or Marketing Ops if you have a use case. We have a limit on seating, but options can be explored.

answers.body:
Stack Overflow for Teams can support Agile software delivery in a variety of ways:

  1. Collaboration and Communication: Agile methodology emphasizes collaboration and communication among team members. Stack Overflow for Teams provides a platform for developers to ask questions and share knowledge, which can foster collaboration and streamline communication.

  2. Knowledge Base: It allows the creation of a knowledge base for the team. This is vital in Agile, as teams often need to refer back to solutions and decisions made in earlier sprints. This helps in maintaining a continuous flow and understanding of the project.

  3. Faster Problem-Solving: Agile teams work in sprints and need to address issues quickly. Stack Overflow for Teams helps in solving problems faster by providing a space where team members can ask questions and get answers from their peers, often much faster than searching the internet or waiting for a scheduled meeting.

  4. Documentation: Agile teams often evolve code and features rapidly. Stack Overflow for Teams can be used to keep documentation up to date. Team members can post explanations, code samples, and other useful information which can serve as a living document.

  5. Integration with Development Tools: Stack Overflow for Teams can be integrated with popular development tools such as Jira, GitHub, and Slack. This ensures that information flows seamlessly among the tools used in the Agile process, making it easier to track issues, share code, and communicate.

  6. Reduced Dependency on Specific Team Members: In Agile teams, it is important to reduce the dependency on specific team members for knowledge. Stack Overflow for Teams allows knowledge to be shared and accessible to all members, which can reduce the 'key person dependency' problem.

  7. Continuous Learning and Improvement: Agile is about continuous improvement. Stack Overflow for Teams facilitates this by providing a platform where team members can learn from each other, share best practices, and collectively improve their skills and knowledge.

  8. Archiving Decision Rationale: During Agile development, numerous decisions are made rapidly. Stack Overflow for Teams can serve as a repository for archiving the rationale behind decisions, which can be very helpful for both current team members and those who join the project at a later stage.

  9. Enhancing Code Quality: By sharing code snippets and getting peer reviews through Stack Overflow for Teams, developers can ensure that code quality is maintained, which is critical for Agile delivery.

  10. Feedback Loop: Agile relies on feedback loops. Stack Overflow for Teams can serve as a platform for giving and receiving feedback, which is crucial for the iterative nature of Agile development.

By leveraging Stack Overflow for Teams effectively, Agile teams can improve collaboration, knowledge sharing, problem-solving, and ultimately deliver high-quality software products in a timely manner.

answers.body:
The default eslint settings for islands live in the islands-scripts workspace where all default configurations are stored (_Scripts/islands/islands-scripts/config/.eslintrc.cjs). This file is shared across all islands and should be edited carefully.

At the moment there is not an easy way to override eslint rules for a specific island unless you completely "eject" from the islands-scripts lint command in your package.json lint script.

{
    "name": "my-island",
    "scripts": {
        "lint": "<you are on your own here>",
     }
}

That said, we should/could consider adjusting the islands-scripts lint command so that teams can add a custom .eslintrc.cjs file in their islands root folder that override the default one. This is not implemented yet though as of today.

comments.body: Related: What is the logic behind the quality standards of posting a question?
Looks like migrated questions (and their answers) never get a QualityScore set.

answers.body:
QualityScore is a basic measure of question and answer quality based on content length and grammar/punctuation heuristics. We then use this score to add posts into the Low Quality review queue if they fall below a particular threshold. The threshold is defined by the NewUserAnswerAdvice.PostQualityReviewThreshold site setting.

QualityScore is calculated when a post is created or edited.

We also typically only look at posts that fall below a minimum length requirement, so the QualityScore isn't guaranteed to be fully calculated for all posts. (Side note: the way the code is written implies that QualityScore should never be null and yet we obviously have those in the database. I'm not sure what's going on with that off-hand.)

In terms of the heuristics, the code itself is the best documentation. It even has useful comments! But in general, we remove code blocks and HTML tags from the content before checking things like length after those removals, whether the post contains spaces, a healthy mix of lowercase and uppercase characters, punctuation, etc. Certain patterns like repeated punctuation, posting an email address, or using emoticon smileys are also penalized. :(

(No emoji checks at this time, though, so 🎉🎉🎉)

comments.body: One major problem here is, regardless of the unique identifier they are using for each account, our account system simply does not support multiple accounts existing with the same email address. Even with other safeguards in place that might prevent auto-merges from occurring, that is a completely untested path to go down that we never anticipated occurring and causes a lot of issues in the system. If they are really trying to create multiple users from the same email address, it will never work properly.
@animuson Thank you, Kyle!

answers.body:
Force reauthentication has no impact on merges - it's just a signal we send to the Identity Provider, asking the Identity Provider to require the user to log in again (and not e.g., using an existing session cookie).

It's also just a request - the Identity Provider is free to ignore or not support it.

The fact that they have multiple users with the same email address isn't really going to work, even if we could change the auto-merge code (which would require a code change), there's a lot of other stuff that might be affected, like email notifications. (It's a bit less of a problem on Enterprise because it handles StackMail Opt-Outs etc. differently than B&B, but it's still a problem).

Can they use plus addressing? For example, mstum+1@stackoverflow.com and mstum+2@stackoverflow.com will not be auto-merged on the Stack Overflow application side, but both still go to my mailbox since our email provider supports that. (SOE definitely has no problem with that, I've successfully used that to create multiple users with a single mailbox for exactly this purpose)

questions.title: When do SOE user credentials get auto-merged? What would justify to "Force reauthentication"?
questions.body:
One of our customers has got quite a special Azure setup. They have multiple Azure users under the same email addresses. But these users have different levels of permission and display names.

We already set the unique identifier to be the userprinciplename so that credentials don't get merged upon account creation.

The problem is that the users might need to constantly switch between users i.e. log out with the "Admin" user and log back in with the "regular" user under different names but the same email address.

As far as we know, the credential would be merged when there are e.g. caching issues or a user hadn't been fully logged out when logging back in with the same browser. Is this correct and expected behavior?

They already set the maximum session length to 60min. as a security policy.

Would it make sense for them to tick "Force reauthentication" in their SAML setup on SOE? To avoid people accidentally merging credentials when logging back in?
Has anyone had a similar case or know what is best here?

They don't want to change their Azure setup and we explained multiple times that it would be more practical to only have 1 user for SOE and highlighted the Pros of this approach.
But 10 users definitely want to have 2 users with this setup to test the different permission settings.

answers.body:
Edit 2023-06-16

We are in a public beta with GitHub now for using GitHub-hosted private runners. These runners are joined to a VNet/subnet in our Azure LZ environment. To use these runners you should update your GHA job to be runs-on: so-private-ubuntu-latest. These private runners are using the same image as ubuntu-latest and the same resource allocations (4 vCPU, etc), so your experience should be identical except now inside the network.

Original answer

DevX is starting to provide this capability through some self-hosted runners on Azure Kubernetes Service. The new so-runner-set is intended for infrastructure and app deployments where access to private networking is required. These are not designed or scaled for general purpose build and test workflows.

To use this new runner you will need to update your GHA job and set it with runs-on: so-runner-set. When your job is submitted to the queue the listener in AKS will pick it up, spawn a new runner pod -- this can take up to 1 minute to create the disk resources for the pod -- and then execute the job on this ephemeral pod. Docker-in-Docker is supported on these runners.

comments.body: You are correct - you cannot use a service key here, at least not the way it's designed to check API keys currently. Because this API is restricted to admins only, we do a lookup for the user tied to the key making the API call, to ensure they are an admin. Because service keys are not tied to a user, the lookup for the user fails with a "User not found" error. It's a little confusing because it's not referring to the user you're trying to modify, but you as the caller of the API.

@animuson Thank you for the confirmation! It's Friday and I don't want to start my weekend feeling like I'm insane. Would you folks be able to add both those things to the documentation (i.e. the error and the requirement to use a user key/token)?
We can ask @LorenAlldrin to see what clarification he thinks is best. Perhaps a note somewhere on that doc clarifying that service keys cannot currently be used for this would be helpful.
@animuson @JonathanKlick Got it: stackoverflow.atlassian.net/browse/PDT-283. I'll clarify in the doc when things settle down a bit around here.

answers.body:
I finally figured it out:

I tried using my personal API key/token and everything works now. It seems that perhaps the "User not found" message was related to using a service key/token (created through admin settings) rather than a specific user key/token.

I think we need to update documentation to reflect a couple of things:

  • The error message and how to handle it

  • Tell the user up front that a service key cannot be used

Again, this was all especially confusing because the API would respond and tell me when I wasn't using an API key or token, but it did NOT tell me the key/token needed to be tied to a specific user.

From a product standpoint, this is more problematic: service keys should be accepted. Customers will likely setup Teams Sync as a regular, automated service. If the key/token must be a associated with a user, that means the Teams Sync will break when that user leaves the organization (thereby disabling their API keys/tokens).

questions.title: "User not found" error when using Teams Sync API
questions.body:
I turned Teams Sync on for API push and enabled it for a specific team.

Keeping it simple, I sent the endpoint a payload for a single user (myself):

[
    {
        "Team": "lunchandlearn",
        "Members": [
            {
                "UserIdentifier": "jklick@stackoverflow.com",
                "Level": "Admin"
            }
        ]
    }
]

As far as I can tell, this follows the JSON format the documentation suggests.

The full API request also seems to be properly URL encoded:

# headers

{'User-Agent': 'python-requests/2.31.0', 'Accept-Encoding': 'gzip, deflate', 'Accept': '*/*', 'Connection': 'keep-alive', 'Content-Type': 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded', 'X-API-Access-Token': 'Nd2R5GaKXSndJv2umKw7dg))', 'X-API-Key': '1oklfJnLqQX49QehDBWP3Q((', 'Content-Length': '176'}

# request body

'requestsJson=%5B%7B%22Team%22%3A+%22lunchandlearn%22%2C+%22Members%22%3A+%5B%7B%22UserIdentifier%22%3A+%22jklick%40stackoverflow.com%22%2C+%22Level%22%3A+%22Admin%22%7D%5D%7D%5D'

I receive an HTTP 400 error in response with the following text:

'{"error_id":407,"error_message":"User not found","error_name":"write_failed"}'

First, I'm not seeing this error message anywhere in the documentation, so it's unclear as to what the issue might be. As far as I can tell, it's trying to say it didn't find the user (me).

Second, I'm pretty confident that our identity provider (Okta) uses email addresses as the UserIdentifier. In fact, when I do a CSV dump of users from the admin panel, I see that the SSO User Identifier is the email address:

Not to mention, the assertion in the SAML config seems to confirm this too:

I'm not sure what to try next to troubleshoot. For now, I've just been trying to break things to see what changes.

  • I tried removing both the access token and key from the request, which triggered different error messages. This confirms that the key/token are accurate.

  • I tried changing the name of the Team to something that doesn't exist, but that didn't trigger a new message. I found this odd because the documentation states there's a status code for TeamNotFound. This led me to believe that I'm somehow formatting the request incorrectly, possibly some minor, stupid mistake.

  • I then sent a BLANK Members array/list with a correct team name and I still got the error message. Now, I'm starting to believe that maybe the "User not found" error is either a red herring or I'm interpreting it completely incorrectly.

  • In fact, if I start changing the structure of the JSON data, changing field names, etc., or even sending a blank JSON, I get the same "User not found" error. This leads me to believe the "User not found" error might be a bit too broad for me to sort out without looking at the code that's generating the message.

comments.body: @TiagoTorre as a knowledge base grows, there will be more and more answers that are not viewed as often over time, so using total questions with answers may undercount the benefit?

@RebekahDumouchelle I think that's definitely a factor to consider. The more unvisited posts in the community there are, the more spread thin the knowledge reuse / page views will be across all posts. It's worth noting that this metric was generated to support POV value realization conversations, I actually haven't ran any analysis with it for established communities.

answers.body:
You need to obtain two metrics:

  1. Number of Page views

  2. Questions with Answers. If you want to be conservative, you could use Questions with Accepted Answers instead

From there, it follows that

Average Page views per Answer = Total Page views / Total Questions with Answers

Method A - Using soe-usage python script

  1. Grab the CSV file output by Jonathan's soe-usage script (example here)

  2. Calculate Total Page views by summing Column B (Aggregate page views)

  3. Calculate Questions with Answers by creating Column Q = G - K

  4. Calculate Total Questions with Answers (Sum up Column Q)

  5. Finally, calculate:

    Average Page views per Answer = Total Page views / Total Questions with Answers

Method A (tag-specific)

You could also run a similar analysis for a specific tag.

After completing Step 2 above, simply divide Column B by Column Q:

Average Tag Page views per Answer = Aggregated Page views (Column B) / Total Questions with Answers (Column Q)

Method B - Using Looker + Amplitude

  1. From the SOE Raw Data Pull look, you can pull the Total Questions with Answers Sum metric

  2. From Amplitude, you could obtain the Cumulative Knowledge Reuse events by using the event Knowledge Reuse Events - Questions with Answers Only

  3. Finally, calculate:

    Average Page views per Answer = Total Questions with Answers Sum / Cumulative Knowledge Reuse events

PS: Depending on the Method you use, you should obtain slightly different results, but the ballpark should be similar. This should give you a strong measure of how often answers are being reused within the community!

comments.body: @animuson to clarify... when I answer my own question after the fact, it doesn't get auto-accepted (based on the testing I did in the demo), but because that site setting is turned on, it removes the 48 hour requirement?
@MikiHunt Correct. I'll clarify my wording a little.
@animuson thanks!

answers.body:
This is tied to a hidden AutoAcceptSelfAnswer setting.

When it's turned on, several things happen:

  • Instant self-answers from the ask question page are auto-accepted upon submission.

  • Users bypass the 48 hour requirement for accepting their own answer.

  • Users bypass the 15 minutes requirement for accepting any answer.

This is off on public sites and users have to wait 48 hours before they can accept a self-answer or 15 minutes for any other answer, but is on for Teams and Enterprise so neither of the wait times for accepting answers will apply.

questions.title: Why is admin role not identified in API response and CSV export?

comments.body: related: Which configuration changes to a customer's hosted instance result in downtime?
I have updated that answer to reflect the new experience and effort

I want to stress that last paragraph. No matter how long or short it takes to implement on our side, we can't do much of it at all before the certificate is delivered in a suitable state as a PFX, see stackoverflowteams.com/c/stack-overflow/questions/15520. ETAs for customers who want a domain change of that sort really can't be given until we get the cert.

answers.body:
Domain changes as a whole have simplified. Domain changes with the suffix .stackenterprise.co do not require a certificate change and therefore it is the fastest change with the shortest amount of downtime.

Domain changes where the suffix is changing from *.stackenterprise.co to <customer-specific> require a customer certificate change and therefore will take longer and will have more downtime. This change also requires a customer certificate before we can change the domain.

answers.body:
A great initial use case for this particular customer, and biotech companies in general, is to capture frequently asked questions about best practices, tools, and processes for experimentation and data analysis. This can help reduce repeat questions, speed up onboarding for new hires or employees joining a new project, prevent productivity blockers, and make adjacent teams aware of all that's involved.

Examples:

  • What are best practices for experimentation and data analysis?

  • What tools do we use for experimentation and how do I get access?

  • What KPIs and success metrics do we track when running experiments?

  • What's the process for running experiments here?

Another use case is to capture and socialize their learnings gained from experiments. This can help break down knowledge silos and encourage more collaboration across teams. And if their ultimate goal is to socialize these experiments with customers, partners, and the general public, capturing this knowledge in Stack Overflow for Teams can keep their customer-facing teams informed.

Lastly, what product lines and services does the company offer? Do they produce pharmaceutical, agricultural, or genomic research products? Or some other type of innovation? Many of our customers find it helpful to capture knowledge about their product lines and product strategies so everyone at the company is aligned, new employees learn quicker, and new innovations are taken to market at a faster rate!

comments.body: Thank you @animuson for the reasoning behind this. Feature request has been submitted!

answers.body:
I'm pretty sure why "why" is a matter of just which numbers are available to the metrics dashboard. I made a cheat sheet for all the values that get pulled, and a lot of other values are simply formulas using variables out of that sheet. There is no value for TotalNonclosedQuestions or anything like that, so they cannot possibly be excluded with the current variables available.

But it's also not as simple as just adding a TotalNonclosedQuestions. But the other variables for answers also have to only account for non-closed questions in order to be accurate. Otherwise, you might end up with values over 100%. That means we'd also have to add values for TotalNonclosedQuestionsWithAnswers and TotalNonclosedAcceptedAnswers at minimum to track that statistic appropriately for non-closed content.

If that's something that is important to Teams communities, you may want to log it in as a feature request to see if it could be addressed. I agree it's weird to include a question as unanswered when it's been signaled it won't ever receive an answer. The only way to solve the problem, though, is to add new queries for new variables that can be used in the formula.

comments.body: Have you shared the PDF version of stackenterprise.freshdesk.com/support/solutions/articles/… with them? (Like is this their estimate in response to that, or in a void?) It certainly doesn't seem like it would take super long if you had someone with the appropriate access rights sit down and do it, but the appropriate access rights part is always the sticky thing. I do think if they have things like internal block lists, etc. it will take longer, so if their estimate is based on past installs, I'd be tempted to believe them.
@EmilyChapman I believe their estimate is in response to that installation article, but I'll need @DillonHayutin to confirm :) I appreciate the additional context Emily!!

answers.body:
The actual, technical installation can be finished in under 30 minutes, and it's not hard when things are straightforward.

However, sometimes clients introduce complications that slow down the process: internal approvals, internal security review, limited people to do the work, or "unexpected" restrictions in their technical environments.

But no, it should not take "hours and hours" unless the client somehow forces that to happen.

The time to configure & install the MS Teams integration itself is not significant. It can be done as quickly as 30 min.

However, the following factors typically slow us down:

  • Security review. Some companies require security approval for the MS Teams integration. They may ask us for additional detail on how we are connecting to MS Teams, what data is exported from their MS Teams environment, what activities are logged by Stack Overflow.

    • To accelerate this, we can share our MS Teams Interaction Diagrams.

  • UAT testing. The customer may require the integration to be tested in a non-production MS Teams environment. I've noticed that this has recently become a common requirement across our STRAT customers.

  • Dependencies on the IT team. They may have competing priorities and/or a backlog of tasks.

As a best practice, the SE should proactively understand the customer's internal process (approvals, steps, timelines) to install MS Teams apps, and work with the AE to escalate as appropriate.

answers.body:
Unfortunately this information isn't available in Amplitude and must be acquired through a database query against the production database. For Basic and Business teams the following query can be run to see which teams have SCIM enabled:

;WITH ChannelInfo AS (
    SELECT [ChannelId]
    FROM [Channels].[dbo].[ChannelSettings]
    WHERE JSON_VALUE(AuthConfigJson, '$.IsEnabled') = 'true' --Scim can't be turned on without sso
        AND JSON_VALUE(AuthConfigJson, '$.ScimProperties.IsEnabled') = 'true'
)
SELECT CI.ChannelId AS ChannelId, S.Name AS TeamName, S.Slug
FROM ChannelInfo AS CI
INNER JOIN Sites.dbo.Sites AS S ON S.Id = CI.ChannelId
WHERE S.SiteStateId = 4 -- 4 = not dead
ORDER BY 1 ASC

I ran this query as of right now and saved the results here if it helps: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1mtHNTMkxYSDn71bYG1QA1lYRRvmjK2DgGSG__u8aPjU/edit?usp=sharing

Please note that just because a team has SCIM enabled doesn't mean they are using it. We have seen some teams in traffic logs that have SCIM enabled but haven't used it at all. Currently we don't store when the last time a customer used their SCIM endpoint.

For enterprise cloud customers, the same query needs to be run against all customer databases by an SRE. Asking in the #teams-scale-pod channel would be your best bet.

Adding this info to Amplitude?

It would be trivial to get this information into Amplitude if we wanted to. Currently we only store two fields on the Account level in amplitude (Amplitude Account = StackOverflow Team):

  • site_created_date

  • registered_users

We could add useful information like is_sso_enabled , is_scim_enabled , etc. and easily see the which customers have it enabled it or not:

If you have access to the support dashboard, whether they have SCIM turned on is already available there.

For example, looking at SO Internal you'd see "SCIM enabled: No" in the Authentication box:

Note that you have to have SSO enabled in order to enable SCIM. If someone doesn't have SSO enabled yet, the other variables will not appear at all and can be assumed off.

This obviously only works for FBB right now. At some point we are supposedly getting a similar support portal for Enterprise but I wouldn't know if it's going to include the same details about their authentication setup.

answers.body:
Events

VSCode has a bit of a weird model where you have to send messages between the UI and the backend of the extension, so you'll often find event names in pairs eg chat->chat (containing the message typed in by the user) and chat->chatResponse (containing the response from the LLM).

To (try to) make it more obvious which ones do which, we included a direction property in the meta data, where eg chat->chat would have a direction of from-webview and chat->chatResponse would have a direction of to-webview

Event Name Definition
chat->requestEmbed The user clicked the Embed Code button
chat-request-embed The extension extracted the users selection
chat->embedResponse The users selection was sent to the chat input box
chat->clear User clicked the Clear Chat button
chat->chat The user has entered a message to the chat bot
chat-execute The extension has sent the user query up to our API (and then onto the LLM)
chat->chatResponse The extension has received a response from the API and has sent it to the UI to display to the user
search->search The user entered a search in the Version A search screen
search->searchResult The extension sent results received from the API back to the UI to display to the user
search-error-on-stack-overflow A user uses quick fix action on an error message to search the error on stackoverflow
search-error-on-stack-overflow-in-chat A user uses quick fix action on an error message to search it on the public site and have the LLM summarize it

Event Properties

Event Property Name Definition
messageHistoryLength The number of user and bot messages in the current chat session
direction For UI messaging, this is either from-webview or to-webview
language The programming language identified by VSCode of the current editor
selection.isEmpty for an embed, was the users selection empty
selection.isSingleLine for an embed, was the users selection a single line or less
viewType The current extension "screen" eg search, chat
User Id Stack Exchange Account Id
Session Id VSCode generated session ID, changes on restart of VSCode
Library The Amplitude SDK Library used, eg Node or Dotnet
Device Id VSCode generated device ID to use as a user identifier before logging in

answers.body:
Traditionally, API support has been provided by our support organization. If customers want help understanding the API or run into issues with the API, they can open a support ticket. Also, Support is usually very clear that they don't help customers build things with the API or troubleshoot things that are not related to the API. We have to draw a line.

I think this is a good approach for sales engineers too. If you're an SE and you happen to understand the API as well as what the customer is trying to achieve, I see no harm with pointing the customer towards the correct API endpoints or educating them on things like filters or creating API keys -- these are also the sorts of things our support organization would help with. Similarly, however, we should probably draw a line when it comes to supporting a customer's creations (vs. supporting the API itself).

In contrast, if you're an SE that doesn't really understand the API, I don't see any harm in sending the customer a link to the documentation or encouraging them to open a support ticket for additional API questions. Another option -- especially when the customer is looking for some thoughtful/consultative guidance -- would be to leverage another SE who is fluent with the API to provide the customer some guidance. As an example, I'm recently getting pulled into a conversations with a customer who is trying to perform a certain type of reporting with our API.

This doesn't seem to be an API issue, but a run-of-the-mill KeyError from Python.

What I'm deciphering is that when you try to use the key data['Title'], 'Title' does not exist.

I think the problem may arise because you're trying to generate payload with data after exiting the for loop. It's likely you want to nest everything within the for loop by indenting like so:

    for index in range(len(df)):
        data = df.loc[index]
        
        # indenting everything below so it stays within the loop
        df.columns = df.columns.str.strip()

        url = 'https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/api/2.3/questions/add'  
    
        payload = {
            
            'title': data['Title'],
            'body': data['Body'],
            'tags': data['Tags'],
            'access_token': 'QBxBucGcS8YPbSiWFkutzA))',
            'preview': 'true',
            'key': 'RWTwPJoVDdPQy8GzMkdKsQ(('
        }
        
        response = requests.post(url, json=payload)
            
        # Process the response
        if response.status_code == 200:
            print('POST request successful')
        else:
            print('POST request failed')

If you continue to get a KeyError after that, you can try to troubleshoot further by adding a small print() statement to inspect the contents of data as it cycles through the for loop.

Example:

    for index in range(len(df)):
        data = df.loc[index]
        print(data)

On a possibly unrelated note...

I'm thinking this line is not doing anything in its current state

df.columns = df.columns.str.strip()

    df = pd.read_csv('/home/1da70697-89c0-49f8-a226-00e407badde0/seeding.csv')

comments.body: Possible duplicate of the "obsolete content shows up in search results" question stackoverflowteams.com/c/stack-overflow/questions/16409

I realize we have an explicit system for identifying "obsolete" content separately, but I never really liked actually retaining that stuff in the first place. There's some value in knowing how things used to work but usually best in context with how stuff currently works rather than sitting as some dampesque in the bay on its own separate charter.

I love obsolete! For example, the FY23 Product vision, roadmap and pods is a great historical record, but now we want to pull up the FY24 version (also, tracking or versioning on Articles is not easy to see what's changed). Similarly, we have launch plans for past Teams features. There's not a "new" way things work now, it was a moment in time.

answers.body:
The ultimate flow of content when it comes to closure is that it either becomes reopened, or it becomes deleted. Closed means people can find it to see if it's still useful, which means they can give feedback that it maybe shouldn't be closed. So finding closed questions via search I would say is a good thing because it allows those posts to actually get dealt with.

  • If a question is closed but it contains information that should remain available, the question should be reworked to a state that it can be re-opened.
  • If a question pertains to information that does not need to be retained, the question should be deleted.
  • If a question is lingering as closed because no one has taken either of the above actions on it, it probably should be evaluated for one of those courses of action.

My understanding is that the most common "lingering" type of closed question is probably stuff that was once relevant but is no longer relevant. People keep them around because it's cool historic knowledge but that starts weighing against the purpose of Stack Overflow for Teams / Enterprise as a knowledge base for people seeking answers to their current problems. The database of information that's retained over years isn't meant to be a chronicle, but it's supposed to reflect that that information is still applicable. We're here to help solve people's problems, not record the company's development history. There's better tooling for that. So old, outdated content only serves as a bad signpost that turns up in search results so that you can hammer it down. That's how I feel about it.

Deletion isn't even a permanent removal tool. The same people who can delete stuff can see deleted stuff and undelete it, making it a perfectly reversible tool. Which makes it very suited to handling information that "No one really should be looking for this stuff so it shouldn't show up for people, but I guess we should keep record of it".

I believe we should leverage Import functionality for performance reasons, and that this will benefit our report viewers and lead to a better experience.

We didn't always have this opinion, but now:

  • Datasets synced to Power BI should be synced to workspaces that are secured by Okta groups. The approval workflow for these groups is managed by our helpdesk team.

  • The security groups managing Power BI report access are separated from the security groups managing Snowflake database access. This is good for principal of least permissions, and also means that we don't have to configure reports to run under the credentials of the executing user when connecting to Snowflake.

One question is still open: are there compliance implications that report authors need to worry about when using the "import" query? I'm checking with our Privacy Counsel for help on confirming this, hopefully will have more info on that soon.

Update: we've found no blockers to using import for this functionality when reviewing this with our Privacy teams. It should be fine to use Import in general. As aways, if you have a concern about data privacy or would like a privacy risk assessment review (no matter what settings your report uses), you can reach out to Stack's privacy team and ask for help.

questions.title: Should we use Direct Query or Import in Power BI?
questions.body:
Power BI Datasets can contain either the compressed imported data (Imported) or the connection properties (Direct Query) from a data source connection.

Are there restrictions on which we should use at Stack, or guidance on choosing between the two?

The following comparison table summarizes Microsoft's descriptions of these two modes:

Import Direct query
How it works Data is synced to blob storage in Azure. When reports run, the data is "local" to the Power BI service (relatively speaking) Data is retrieved from the data source on every execution from the Power BI service. If the data is in Snowflake, that means going to another Azure region, authenticating to Snowflake, running the query (results may be cached in snowflake following the first query run, at times), and then retrieving results.
Scheduled refreshes Data syncs can be scheduled for regular refresh (note: this may not work in every case -- if you have some Import and some Direct Query in a single .pbix, that might break this, for example) No refresh as there is no synced copy in Azure blob storage used as the basis of the report
Report performance Usually better for report viewers, as the data results have already been cacluated and synced to azure Usually worse for report viewers, may not be problematic for very fast queries, though
Report authoring Imported datasets have some extra functionality such as Quick Insights, automatic creation of Date Hierarchies, and... not having to use DAX. You gotta use DAX 🤷‍♀️
Where does this approach shine? Everyday reports where it's acceptable to sync the data to the Power BI service. This is useful in cases where Import doesn't work. Examples: There isn't enough memory to load the imported model when it's queried or refreshed. The most recent data is always important to query so a scheduled refresh doesn't work.
Who can see the data in Power BI? This is governed by the security groups set up on the Power BI workspace -- this is the same for both options. This is governed by the security groups set up on the Power BI workspace -- this is the same for both options.

External documentation:

  • https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/connect-data/service-dataset-modes-understand
  • https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/connect-data/desktop-use-directquery

Benefits

[User] empowers a faster and more effective onboarding process for new users and improves engagement with existing users by providing a more immersive experience through features like in-app tours, tooltips, checklists, and new feature highlights.

Intercom does utilize automation so we can automatically trigger messages or flows based on events like a user onboarding flow for a new user.

answers.body:
History of Site Satisfaction Survey reporting and Qualtrics

Stack Overflow uses the Qualtrics 3rd party service to host multiple surveys, including the Site Satisfaction Survey.

In the past, analytics for this survey were set up in R Studio. However, due to credential issues, reports stopped functioning. R Studio is also going to be decommissioned by Stack in the near future, as it has minimal users and a significant annual cost.

To maintain reporting functionality, the Data Platform team ran analytics manually for a while for the Site Satisfaction Survey, then set up a custom API pull using Databricks. This data feed refreshes daily and sends data to the Azure Data Lake and the Qualtrics database in Snowflake. Power BI dashboards read from this data in Snowflake.

Future use case puzzles: FiveTran, Compliance, and Surveys

Stack now has licenses for FiveTran, which offers standardized connectors for 3rd party APIs and is desirable for future use cases in general.

However, there are security concerns with any setup using the Qualtrics API, whether by Fivetran or otherwise. Factors in the puzzle:

  • A Data Privacy review is required for ingesting new surveys.
  • Qualtrics provides only a single API key per user, and that key has access to all surveys the user has permission to.
  • Fivetran doesn't offer row-level filtering, so there's arisk of importing data without Data Privacy review if a new survey is shared with the account doing the data pull.
  • For custom API pulls, it's crucial to write code that pulls only a specific survey, but this can be complex due to the lack of an easy way to pull a normalized schema.

Based on these factors, to pull data for an additional Qualtrics survey into the Data Platform, care will need to be taken to ensure that the right tool is used and that the configuration does not result in surveys that haven't been reviewed and approved by Stack's Data Privacy Team "leaking" into the platform.

For future reference, the name of the survey that Databricks notebook is pulling in is "Site Satisfaction Tracking Survey". The survey ID is SV_b14eaLcRaiLlZMF. The data-team@stackoverflow.com account doesn't own this survey so this survey has to be shared with the data team account for us to be able to pull data from it.

answers.body:
I can think of several possibilities:

  1. Limit access to SO to members of specific groups
  2. Assign permissions based on group membership
  3. Handle membership in private teams based on the group membership
  4. Job title/department for the Connectivity feature

Limit access to SO to members of specific groups

On B&B, this is not possible and needs to be handled on the IdP - users shouldn't even be able to log in. On Enterprise, we also recommend handling it in the Identity Provider and preventing people to log in.

That's how we do it ourself:

However, we do have a feature called SAML Access Rules that can be used to limit who can log in to SOE. This is a bit of a last resort, because if you get the Access Rules wrong, you can permanently lock out everyone from the instance and require support to manually turn off the Access Rule enforcement.

Assign permissions based on group membership

E.g., "everyone in the soe-admins group should be flagged as Administrator"

We do NOT support doing that from the Authentication, because people only log into SAML every so often, so role changes could take days before someone logs in via SAML again.

On Enterprise, you can use SCIM to make someone a Moderator, though we don't support making someone an Administrator ("Developer") user through that.

On B&B, SCIM support also exists and allows making someone a Team Admin.

Handle membership in private teams based on the group membership

E.g., "I'm a member of the data-team group, so I should be added to the 'Data Team' and 'User Research 2023' private teams on Enterprise"

We don't support this from SAML for the same reason as above (people logging in through SAML too infrequently), but on Enterprise there's a Team Membership Sync feature that can be used. I highly recommend the "Syncing Team Membership via API Push" approach since it gives the customer complete control over the timing, and doesn't require punching a hole into their own firewall for us to access their source of truth.

Job title/department for the Connectivity feature

I don't think that's what they mean, but I know that some companies refer to departments as "groups", so maybe they mean the new connectivity feature that gets Job Titles and Departments and shows a graph between them: https://stackoverflowteams.com/c/stack-overflow/articles/22213

The name of the attribute can be setup in SAML Settings on both Enterprise (since 2023.1) and B&B:

questions.title: Group Claim in SAML for SSO configuration
questions.body:
I got this question from a customer and, not being a SAML expert, was a little flummoxed even though I know the big picture aspects of setting up SSO. Can someone help me understand what is being asked and how we should respond?

We currently return a group claim in our OKTA response.  However, this is not being used today because it wasn’t supported originally (is my understanding).  Our understanding is that this is now supported.  What would need to enable this functionality?  I tried to poke around the admin settings on the console, but didn’t see anything that jumped out at me.  Also tried to look at docs, but didn’t find anything.

answers.body:
There's no issue with an SO employee going the extra mile and providing a customer with a code snippet or working script as long as expectations are provided upfront to the customer. We do not have the resources to get pulled into full support for these types of requests. Please provide the following (feel free to re-write it in you're own words) when providing any code snippets or scripts:

Please note that these scripts are offered with no further support. These examples work on our test servers, but you are responsible for modifying, testing, and implementing these files for your use.

Support has three scripts currently that can be shared with clients to assist with their requests for bulk deactivation and deletion action via SCIM API.

Please note that the following statement still holds when sharing scripts with clients. These scripts are meant to give clients a headstart on what they need.

Please note that these scripts are offered with no further support. These examples work on our test servers, but you are responsible for modifying, testing, and implementing these files for your use.

With that said, here are links to the internal Stack Overflow Github page where they live:

get_all_users.py :

This script will create a .csv file containing all the users (AccountID, DisplayName, & Email) from an instance. The Python script will prompt the user to enter their BaseURL and the API Key from their Admin Settings.

bulk_deactivate_users.py :

This script will take in a .csv file that only needs to contain the column EmailAddress and the emails of the users that the client wishes to have deactivated. This script will prompt the user to enter their BaseURL, SCIM Bearer Authentication Token (this value is set by the client on the SCIM Admin Settings page of their instance) & the file path of the .csv file. As a precaution to prevent Stack Overflow from providing a script that will bulk changes on a client's DB the user of the script will be prompted to confirm the action should be taken on the user. If the client wishes to have this removed to just automatically perform they will need to change the code themselves.

bulk_delete_users.py :

This script will perform just like the deactivate script. It will take in a .csv file that only needs to contain the column EmailAddress and the emails of the users that the client wishes to have deleted. This script will prompt the user to enter their BaseURL, SCIM Bearer Authentication Token (this value is set by the client on the SCIM Admin Settings page of their instance) & the file path of the .csv file. As a precaution to prevent Stack Overflow from providing a script that will bulk changes on a client's DB the user of the script will be prompted to confirm the action should be taken on the user. If the client wishes to have this removed to just automatically perform they will need to change the code themselves.

comments.body: Related: CM Best Practices: How do I know when to respond/not respond to a comment or question on a Meta post? (which is also linked in your answer below), How can I feature a post on Meta Stack Exchange or Meta Stack Overflow? (which links to the same Google form as your answer below does)

answers.body:
Structure

When it comes to writing a Meta post, there isn’t a one-size-fits-all answer when it comes to length, but a good rule of thumb is that you should be providing clear context and all of the essential details and clear actions/asks for the community.

Zach Rutta has written a structured outline that is clear to follow and works for any type of Meta post:

  • Specific title

  • Introduction/Background 

    • Assume that not everyone in the community has historical context (provide definitions, links to previous posts, etc.)

    • Assume that not everyone in the community is familiar with abbreviations. If it is necessary to abbreviate, first spell out the entire phrase first and then use parentheses (e.g. "Code of Conduct (CoC)"). From here, you can use the abbreviated phrase in the post.

  • Body

    • What we’re solving for

    • Who is the intended user - who will benefit?

    • Screenshots and/or demo video

  • Closing

    • Call for input from the community (make it clear if this is an ask for feedback or if this is an announcement, and people may ask questions or raise concerns as answers or comments) 

    • If we are following up, provide a date and what we will be following up with (results of an experiment, 

  • Optional:

    • Share code package, if applicable. In some releases, users in the community can download and run the code themselves.

Additional best practices around structure

  • Avoid hypotheticals and going out into the weeds, as that can distract from the main takeaways you want the community to focus on.

  • While length will vary depending on the information you need to share, being as concise as possible is always best. If your post is more lengthy, a TL;DR at the top is suggested so readers don’t glaze over and miss takeaways or calls to action.

  • Be specific about any asks. If you are asking for input in your closing, make it really clear what the CTA is, and if there is a deadline for sharing feedback, make sure you include that.

  • Meta is a bit different than posting on some other platforms. While staff should have a unified voice, it is also okay and encouraged to let some of your personality come out in your writing. It humanizes you to the community. Humor can be helpful, but you don’t want to overdo it with jokes and analogies. Remember that we are writing for an international audience, and some humor doesn’t translate well.

The editing process

Make sure you have at minimum two other pairs of eyes on the copy before it’s finalized and posted. Most of us are great at catching typos and other errors in other people’s work, but we’re often too close to our work to see our own errors.

If you aren’t sure about an important technical aspect, timeline, etc., make sure that you flag that to the project owner (or the person responsible for the piece you aren’t sure of). Posting misinformation and having to retract it isn’t a great experience for the community or for us.

If you think something is going to be controversial, it’s really important to make sure the V.P. of the Community, Product Marketing, and Matt Trocchio are aware.

Ensuring stakeholders are aware of major announcements

Zach Rutta has created a checklist for posters to follow so stakeholders are looped into any major announcements and releases.

Checklist

  • Add the post to the Meta Post Google Calendar as soon as you have a target post date

  • If the post needs to be featured on MSO or MSE, fill out this Google Form at least a week prior to your preferred posting date.

  • Create a Meta post Release Email the day before the post

    • Include the following stakeholders who should receive the Meta Post Release Email:

      • cogro@stackoverflow.com, pbeaudette@stackoverflow.com 

      • mtrocchio@stackoverflow.com

      • team-cprod-product-managers@stackoverflow.com, des@stackoverflow.com 

      • customersupport@stackoverflow.com 

      • jcicmanliuzzo@stackoverflow.com, cthomas@stackoverflow.com, mtien@stackoverflow.com,  tgaraas@stackoverflow.com, jhindle@stackoverflow.com, zrutta@stackoverflow.com, rcollia@stackoverflow.com 

      • ltoy@stackoverflow.com, sbell@stackoverflow.com , bdirker@stackoverflow.com

    • Details to include in the Meta Post Release Email:

      • Subject: "[Meta Post Alert] Name of Feature/Product"

      • Meta Post Location: Meta Stack Overflow (MSO) or Meta Stack Exchange (MSE) or specific Stack Exchange Meta page

      • Date of Meta Post

      • Will this post be featured?

      • A TL;DR summary of the post

      • Specifics around what to expect

      • User Impact

        • Moderator impact

          • Do we need to collect feedback from moderators in advance? 

          • Do moderators or other user stakeholders need advance notice of the upcoming post?

        • Editor/Curator impact

        • Consumer impact

      • Who will be monitoring Meta and for how long?

      • How long will we be actively monitoring the post?

      • Does the Meta post need a follow-up after a certain period of time (e.g. updating the post that the experiment is concluded, providing results of the experiment, etc.)? When will we be following up with Meta?

Monitoring the post

Make sure that you, the author, and/or anyone who has been tasked with keeping an eye on the Meta post for the designated period of time is doing so. 

If you are working with a Product Manager or other product stakeholder, be sure to distill the feedback to the stakeholders and seek assistance if you are unsure how to respond to something. This guide on when to respond and what to respond to on Meta is also worth checking out.

Closing the loop

If we’ve communicated that we’re collecting feedback or input through a certain period of time, it’s good practice to follow up when that feedback loop has been closed. If there are learnings, updates, or next steps as a result of a release, we should also be including those in the post wrap-up.

answers.body:
Stack Overflow for Teams is now hosted on Microsoft's Azure cloud with our Teams datacenter environment serving as a secondary failover site, completing Blueshift Phase 4: Azure Primary.

Next, in Phase 5: "Cutting the Cord," the Blueshift team will remove all dependencies on the DC for Teams hosting and decommission the Teams DC environment. The Azure production environment will serve as the Teams primary hosting environment, operating under ISO and SOC2 controls, certificates, and attestations. This is targeted for completion at the end of June 2023. Upon completion of Phase 5, Blueshift will be complete!

On July 5, 2023, we will launch our go-to-market plan announcing these changes and benefits to customers, including assets and collateral to promote our SOC2 compliance for the Business tier. Until then, please hold off on communicating details to the public. We will provide enablement for field teams. Stay tuned for updates!

To further your understanding and prepare to speak to the value of this cloud migration, please read this article.

If they did Sunday-Saturday of that week for his email, for example, this would essentially leave out activity from Thursday afternoon through Saturday, and users who earn rep during those days would never receive credit.

When speaking with customers, encourage them to set their time frame around what makes sense for capturing the most data that best represents the time frame of their weekly newsletter leaderboards rather than simply representing the actual calendar week. If a customer wants both, my suggestion would be to report on top weekly users the following Monday so you've captured a true representation of the data for the calendar week.

Specifically, bookmarking questions doesn't do anything special for you, other than give you an easy way to find that question later. In contrast, following a question or answer generally gives you all notifications for activity by others on that post, as if you wrote it yourself – you'll be notified if the post is edited, commented on, or answered (if it's a question).

answers.body: Not only do you have the option to bookmark questions, you have the ability to follow them, too. You will receive notifications on activity as it occurs. The option to follow appears below "people asked."

Following a question gives you the ability to get question-level updates instead of tag-level. I don't follow questions often, but when I do it's usually because I want to be notified of the latest answers since it's a question that's relevant to my job. If it's knowledge that I want to reuse later, I bookmark it.

comments.body: The one caveat here is that I would probably not use TEI for upsells into net new teams/departments. I think it would more impactful to extrapolate the current actual KRs into the new department. I don't think usage rates would be wildly different for other BUs within an organization.e.g., 2000 KR events per week for 1000 users would extrapolate to 3000 KR events per week for 1500 users (assuming a 500 seat upsell). If you net out the original 2k KR events and 1k users that would be 1k KR events that you can drop into the calculator.

@JohnTeuber  I was told that the TEI would be used when upselling into a large group of new users.  To confirm, you are suggesting KR 2.0 for all cases with existing clients and TEI for only pre-sales.   Correct?

answers.body:
Think of the TEI vs KR2.0 as Predicted value versus Actual value.

Predicted: The TEI calculator should be used during the pre-sales process and when upselling into net new teams/departments (think significant growth). You enter assumptions to predict the value to be realized.

Actual: The KR 2.0 calculator should be used to show the value organizations have received and will receive during a given period for existing clients.

answers.body:
It's still enabled by the looks of it.

When posts are created by anonymous users, we create an User with UserTypeId.Unregistered. Those anonymous users have a user in the DB, and an Account in the SitesDB with Unregistered account type id. Their user credential is stored in a session cookie, so they can post multiple times from that session. If they decide to sign up (or join another site, at which point we'll ask them to add a credential), the their UserTypeId and AccountTypeId changes to Registered.

answers.body:
I have not seen exactly what you're describing, but I do know of a large customer that is integrating a few similar redirection opportunities in the ticketing workflow. Here they are in the order a user / ticket opener would encounter them...

  1. On the developer portal mainpage, a stack icon is presented inside of each product's tile (where the ticket workflow is also initiated from). This stack icon is paired with a count of answered questions in SO for the related tag, and clicking either the icon or the number will take them to that tag page on SOE.

  2. Once the user initiates a ticket for that product, they are asked for details (a title, severity level, etc). Clicking next sends the title text to SOE via the search API endpoint and returns the top 5 most relevant posts from SOE to an interstitial page, encouraging the user to abandon the ticket if one of those posts resolves their issue.

  3. If the user continues the ticketing workflow, their ticket gets opened and the classic JIRA integration stuff applies (where the JIRA user can surface posts from SOE if applicable).

All that noted, I do think some kind of suggest could make sense. Another neat idea might be to allow the support engineer to resolve the ticket and offer to either the User or Support engineer to convert the ticket to an SO post. In that case, we might open via API a new question from the ticket text, and then post an answer using the resolution text, offering one or both users the opportunity to edit for clarity, conciseness, or sanitizing personal or irrelevant details.

answers.body:
See this article explaining the error rate monitors. We should be iteratively working towards having useful alerts that trigger only when important things are actually going wrong.

If you click on the alert heading in Slack, it should take you to Datadog, where you can edit the monitor. Here are some things you can try tweaking:

  1. Mute it for that specific route. Routes such as get_/axis-media/media.amp probably should error 100% of the time - they're nothing to worry about. Be careful not to mute the whole monitor for every route.

  2. Increase the cutoff_min for the error metric. It could be that a handful of errors caused the rate to jump above the threshold for a small blip. The alert likely resolved itself very quickly and just adds to the noise. Using a higher absolute cutoff means only endpoints with a higher overall

  3. Increase the threshold. 10% might be too sensitive. Maybe nudge this up to 20%? (Be sure to change the alert description to match this)

  4. Use a different timespan. Maybe 5 minutes is too quick, let's try 10 minutes? (Be sure to change the alert description to match this)

Be careful not to nudge any of these too far in the other direction, where our alerts don't trigger when real things are going wrong.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Stack Overflow? Why?

answers.body:
If possible, use a Site Setting as a way to feature flag, because it makes conditional checks easier.

For example:

// Enabled only on the SE Network, not on Teams F&B&B or Enterprise
// Access with SiteSettings.Global.Foo.EnableMyFeatureFor.ContainsCurrentSite()

[CoreDefaultValue(SiteSelector.Values.All)] // Note: This still applies to the Blueshift TeamsShellSite :/
[CoreChannelsDefaultValue(SiteSelector.Values.None)]
[EnterpriseDefaultValue(SiteSelector.Values.None)]
[Description("My awesome feature!")]
[GlobalOnly]
public SiteSelector EnableMyFeatureFor { get; }

or

// Enabled only on the SE Network, not on Teams F&B&B or Enterprise
// Access with "if (Current.Settings.Foo.EnableMyFeature)" or make it
// [GlobalOnly] and use SiteSettings.Global.Foo.EnableMyFeature
[CoreDefaultValue(true)] // Note: This still applies to the Blueshift TeamsShellSite :/
[CoreChannelsDefaultValue(false)]
[EnterpriseDefaultValue(false)]
[Description("My awesome feature!")]
public bool EnableMyFeature { get; }

Because DefaultValue/CoreDefaultValue still applies to the Blueshift TeamsShellSite, you might want to add the defaults to environmentSettings.*.json instead for Non-Enterprise builds. (At the time of writing, Enterprise does not fully use environmentSettings.json, so use EnterpriseDefaultValue for now)

If that's not an option (e.g., no Current.Site/HTTP Request Context), you can use the various Env options:

if (Env.IsPublic)
{
    // SE Network
}

if (Env.IsBlueshift)
{
    // Teams F&B&B: Individual Teams and the Channels Root Site
    // INCLUDING the TeamsShellSite

    if (Current.IsChannelsApp)
    {
        // EXCLUDING the TeamsShellSite
    }
    else
    {
        // ONLY on the TeamsShellSite
    }
}

if (Current.Site.IsTeamsShellSite)
{
    // Alternative to "Env.IsBlueshift && !Current.IsChannelApp"
}

if (Env.IsEnterprise)
{
    // Enterprise Main Site
    // OR
    // Enterprise Private Teams

    if (Current.IsChannelsApp)
    {
        // EXCLUDING the Enterprise Main Site
    }
    else
    {
        // ONLY on the Enterprise Main Site
    }
}

if (Current.Site.IsEnterpriseMainSite) {
    // Alternative to "Env.IsEnterprise && !Current.IsChannelsApp"
}

If you want to exclude/include something specifically for Enterprise and don't even want to compile it, you can use conditional compilation. You should avoid this.

#if !ENTERPRISE
public void NonEnterpriseOnly()
{
    MakeServiceCall("HardcodedSecretThatShouldReallyBeInEnvironmentSettingsJson");
}
#endif

#if ENTERPRISE
public void EnterpriseOnly()
{
    DoStuffOnlyOnEnterprise();
}
#endif

or alternatively (but still undesireable)

[Conditional("INTERNAL")]
public void NonEnterpriseOnly()
{
}

[Conditional("ENTERPRISE")]
public void EnterpriseOnly()
{
}

answers.body:
To connect to a VM, you first have to use PIM and then use Bastion to get into the VM.

PIM

To get permissions on Azure to connect to a VM (or anything else) you first need to elevate your permissions. This can be done by activating Azure Privileged Identity Management (PIM).

Easiest is to search for PIM in the Azure Portal:

Select My Roles:

And then Groups:

Here you can see the eligible groups that you can elevate your permissions to. If you want to access something on dev, choose pim-az-lz-teams-dev-developer, for Prod choose pim-az-lz-teams-prod-developer. Prod will require you to get approval, Dev can be activated without approval from someone else but all actions will be logged and are available in the audit logs of Azure.

Click on Activate and wait for the portal to finish applying your new permissions. By default, the permissions will be available for the next 4 hours. You can decrease this if you want but you can never go above the 4 hours.

Although the portal states that you don’t have to logout/login for the permissions to apply, this is not always true. If after activating PIM you still get a permissions denied error anywhere in the portal, try logging out and in to see if that fixes it.

Bastion

Now that you have the required permissions, the next step is to figure out which VM you want to connect to.

Most common resource groups are:

  • rg-eastus-qc

    • Dev

    • Prod

  • rg-qe-hk

Each resource group contains a Virtual Machine Scale Set:

A VMSS has one or more instances:

When you select an instance, you get the option to connect through Bastion:

You can enter the username yourself (LocalAdmin) and then select the password from the infra Key Vault for the resource group that you’re working with:

If you get an error that you are not allowed to list the Key Vault secrets make sure that you are using the full VPN.

Once you click Connect, Bastion will load in the browser and give you access to the VM.

If you want, you can also use a native RDP client to Bastion into the VMs which is documented here: How do I use the Bastion Native Client functionality to connect to an Azure VM on a non-windows PC?

questions.title: How do I connect to a dev or production VM in Azure to do some debugging?

answers.body:
StackOverflow Teams uses SQL Server VMs that are managed by DBRE. These servers are fine tuned to run the production load we have when it comes to request and the sheer number of channels we store.

We use these SQL Server VMs in both the dev and prod tenant for eastus and westus.

Now we also wanted an easy way to spin up  an environment on demand for testing infrastructure and app changes without having DBRE to come in and manually install and configure a SQL Server VM for us. Because of this we can also configure a tenant to use SQL Azure for the databases. This is a hosted version of SQL Server that doesn’t require VM maintenance or SQL Server installations. For example, the tenants QE (for Mabl) and latest (for app and infra tests) all use SQL Azure.

Terraform creates the SQL Azure instance for us and the empty databases that we need. We then run StackOverflow.Setup against these databases to initialize the schemas and insert all the required data to get started with a new environment. This is why the run database migrations step in the Stack Overflow for Teams project checks if the databases are initialized and if not runs StackOverflow.Setup to initialize the new SQL Azure resource.

answers.body:
In Octopus Deploy, a tenant is treated like a smaller slice of an environment. Octopus creates a new deployment for every tenant/environment combination you are deploying a release into.

We have three environments:

  • Infradev: used by SRE to test infrastructure changes

  • Dev: home to various tenants used for application testing

  • Prod: home to the production tenants that we use for customers

Within each environment we have multiple tenants. Here is a screenshot of the tenants we use:

As you can see, CustX SREs have their own tenants so they can test infrastructure changes independent of each other.

Some other important tenants:

  • eastus: this is the tenant used to host stackoverflowteams.dev and stackoverflowteams.com.

  • westus: this is the HADR tenant for stackoverflowteams.com

  • qe: used by our QA engineers to run Mabl tests against Teams

  • latest: used to test the combination of new infra and app changes.

Normally you will work most with the eastus tenant in the dev and prod environment.

questions.title: What tenants and environments do we use in Octopus?
questions.body: I’ve seen that we have a dev and prod environment but we also have something called qe and eastus. What’s that all about?

answers.body:
Octopus has a layered system of variables that are all collected when creating a release and then used during deployment.

Teams Variable Set

A variable set is defined in the Octopus library and can be used by all projects in that Octopus space.

The Teams variable set contains shared variables such as connection strings and environment site settings.

For example, EnvironmentSiteSettings:Analytics:InternalStoreEnabled corresponds to the following JSON snippet in the environment settings file:

{
  "EnvironmentSiteSettings": {
    "Analytics": {
      "InternalStoreEnabled": false
    },
…
}

You can add new values here and define the scope where they should apply. Creating a new release will pick up these values and use them during deployment.

Tenant variables

While creating the infrastructure through Terraform, we push certain values that are specific per tenant (e.g. dev, prod, qe) to Octopus so we can reuse those values during deployment.

All these values are auto created during deployments and changing them actually requires changing the Terraform code and doing a new infra deployment. You should not change these values manually.

Project variables

Finally you have variables that are scoped to a specific project. These values are not shared with other projects.

During a deployment, the variable sets, tenant variables and project variables are collected and applied to all steps.

If you want to figure out how Octopus gets to a certain value you can use the Preview option on a Project. Here you can select your environment, tenant and deployment step to see which values are used by Octopus and validate them before deploying.
