answers.body:
All apps we deploy for Teams have two health endpoints that you can check:

  • Readiness indicates if the app is running normally but isn't ready to receive requests: /health-checks/ready

  • Liveness indicates if an app has crashed and must be restarted: /health-checks/live

Application Gateway checks the ready endpoint for all apps to determine if it can send traffic to that app.

Health endpoints

To see how this is implemented in code, the ChannelsDbApi is the easiest example to look at. ChannelsDbApi is fully self contained and does not share any code with other parts of the monolith (the same is true for Scheduler, TagServer and StackMail).

In Startup we register the health checks middleware that Microsoft provides and we add the specific health checks we want to use for the ready and live endpoints.

https://github.com/StackEng/StackOverflow/blob/ef3a1b3cad6ba39e3bc8fbb0a0d3c3cb431a9b87/StackOverflow.ChannelsDbApi/Startup.cs#L112-L127

We also add a special type of middleware called the `HealthCircuitBreakerMiddleware`. This middleware listens to `/deployment/open-drain-circuit-breaker` and if called triggers a circuit breaker that marks the app as unhealthy, independent of the actual healthy state. This is used during deployments to mark an app as unhealthy to make sure that App Gateway doesn’t send traffic to it and we can safely deploy a new app.

https://github.com/StackEng/StackOverflow/blob/ef3a1b3cad6ba39e3bc8fbb0a0d3c3cb431a9b87/StackOverflow.ChannelsDbApi/HealthChecks/HealthCircuitBreakerMiddleware.cs#L8-L35

All health endpoints and the circuit breaker are limited to internal clients only. This to avoid exposing sensitive information externally or having clients call the circuit breaker to bring our app down.

See the Microsoft documentation for more information on how health checks work: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/host-and-deploy/health-checks

Deployment pipeline

All our pipelines follow the general pattern that you can see in the following screenshot:

First, we mark an app as unhealthy in App Gateway to make sure App Gateway stops sending traffic to the app. This is done by an Octopus worker calling the deployment circuit breaker that each app has. We then wait until App Gateway reports the app as unhealthy before continuing with the deployment.

Once the deployment is finished, we wait for the newly deployed app to become healthy. We do this by monitoring App Gateway for that specific app instance. Once the app is healthy, we can safely move to the next VM and repeat until all VMs have the new deployment.

If an app does not report healthy within a specified time frame, we fail the deployment and stop the deployment before it would take out all VMs in the environment.

The script that handles the marking an app as unhealthy and waiting for an app to become healthy is stored in Octopus as a Step Template.

The script takes several parameters and implements both the wait and drain capability. If you need to make changes to this script, you can do that here. Once you save the update, you have to update the step template reference in all deployment projects so they all use the new version. The Usage tab can help you figure out where the step template is used.

questions.title: How do our rolling deployments and health checks for Teams work in Azure?
questions.body: I know we have added health checks to all our apps so we can do rolling deployments but how does this work and where do I start if I want to add a health check?

answers.body:
The following diagram shows how we’ve set up our Azure infrastructure.

Source: https://app.diagrams.net/#G1oE7kXinw4AREauEbmUUW7yrfn7-rblYA

All infrastructure code uses Terraform and PowerShell and can be found here: https://github.com/StackEng/infrastructure-teams.

  1. All external traffic is handled through Fastly. This is where the vanity domains such as stackoverflowteams.dev or integrations.stackoverflowteams.com are handled and where a request comes into our application. We use Public and Private DNS zones to configure our domains.

  2. The request is then forwarded to Application Gateway. We have an internal and external App Gateway. The external Application Gateway listens to https requests and uses mTLS to ensure requests are only coming from Fastly (requests that do not present the correct certificate are dropped - see How do I test requests against the Azure Application Gateway with Blueshift? for a mechanism to test the AppGW directly by mimicking the mTLS process). The internal App Gateway is used to provide access to services within the private network (not going through the internet). This is useful to access services that are not exposed externally, like ChannelsDBApi, but also for communication between different services, even if they are exposed externally

  1. The App Gateway checks which route to hit and if that route has a healthy backend. The request is then forwarded to a Web Server VM in the Virtual Machine Scale Set (VMSS).

We use only one VMSS, where every VM in it hosts all the apps needed to run the Teams network. When a new VM is added to the VMSS, a base image (that we also build ourselves with the latest patches) is used and Octopus is automatically triggered to deploy all the apps to it.

  1. On the VMs we use IIS to host all apps. Each app listens to a specific host, we no longer have the * binding that is used by the multi tenant public website. The app handles the request and connects to the database

  2. The database is hosted on Virtual Machines running SQL Server (these are not part of the main VMSS). We have two VMs that are grouped together for high availability. We connect to a listener that then forwards the SQL connection to the read/write primary or the read only secondary.

  1. Azure Redis is used for caching. This is a hosted Redis service that we don’t have to maintain ourselves but is delivered as a service by Azure. We host multiple Redis caches for the different Redis connections that the app requires.

  1. The same is true for Elastic. Each environment has its own ElasticSearch cluster that’s fully managed by Elastic.

All networking is done with virtual networks. Each layer of the application resides in its own subnet so we can add network security rules between all the subnets to restrict traffic.

We also have two Key Vaults that are used to store secrets. The infra Key Vault contains secrets like the local admin password for the VMs and a list of all URLs and connection strings in the environment. The SQL key vault contains all the SQL users and passwords and the name of the SQL Server (or listener) to connect to.

If you want to look for yourself, you can find the dev environment in the resource group rg-eastus-qc in the Azure portal.

questions.title: What does the Teams architecture in Azure look like?
questions.body: Now that Teams is running in Azure I want to get up to speed on how we architected things. Do we have some information on this?

answers.body:
Disclaimer:  The information below is a general guideline and includes personal recommendations for what to look for when it comes to all things Home Internet. Because of the wide variety of issues and constraints, IT cannot provide support for home internet and will defer to your Internet Service Provider(ISP), suggesting to test on a known good connection (Coffee Shop, Library, public wifi).

How to test your internet connection

Terms to know, their meaning, general guidelines and what to look for when selecting an internet provider:

Download speed: The speed at which data, including files, web sites, pictures, music, and movies, is being delivered to you from the Internet. www.fast.com - This website will allow you to test your download speeds.

Upload speed:  The opposite of download. The speed at which data is being delivered from your device to the Internet. www.fast.com - If you click on the more info button (once the download speed is finished its test), you will be able to see your Upload speeds as well.

Latency: The time delay or how long data takes to travel between the sender and the receiver. www.fast.com - Same as above. The more info button will allow you to see the Latency of your internet connection.

There are other websites that do similar tests, but I find fast.com the most reliable and consistent. As always a quick google search for ‘internet connection test’ will probably bring you to some of the more popular ones.

Home Internet

General guidelines to look for when selecting internet provider and service.

  • As a general rule as a minimum you should strive for 10 mbps download and 10 mbps upload per device.

  • For a family of 2-4 people we recommend a minimum internet connection of 100 download / 100 upload.

  • The Latency of your internet connection will vary depending on the type of service you have available to you. Fiber has the lowest latency and it can sit as low as 5ms. Cable can go as low as 10-20 ms. DSL can be in the 20-40 ms range. Satellite connections are hard to predict but they can be 150+ ms.

Please keep in mind that your internet service numbers will vary depending on your location and time of day. Also internet service connection to your home does not equal internet service to your devices. That’s why it's important to have quality Home WiFi equipment that has good coverage for your homes. For more information read the next section.

Home WiFi

Recommendations for WiFi equipment

These recommendations are somewhat subjective. Options are given in case people are not sure what to pick. Equipment should be placed in the most central location to ensure ideal coverage across the house/apartment.

Budget - TP-Link AC1750 Router

Mid-range - TP-Link AX5400 WiFi 6 Router

Mesh WiFi (for coverage of bigger homes, up to 5000 sq ft) - Google WiFi (usually covers up to 1500 sq ft per puck) or TP-Link Deco Mesh WiFi System (Deco M5)

High-end and gaming - Asus ROG Rapture WiFi 6 (GT-AX11000)

answers.body:
I would counter the objection of the customer by splitting the journey into two parts.

As a first note, I would say it's important to manage expectations for POVs. Also the term Proof-of-Value can be somewhat deceiving because to prove value you first need to build something that will provide you with that value (i.e. a knowledge-sharing community). I will sometimes even refer to a POV as Proof-of-Adoption on a side note to the customer, to reinforce where the focus for a POV lies.

1) POV / Initial Community building (2-3 months)

  • During this phase, the focus is on building a healthy knowledge-sharing community from the ground up (vs. realizing value from an already functioning community).

  • Building a successful community takes time and effort, and from our experience instantiating thousands (15,000) of private communities, we learned what is required to do this successfully. This includes time commitment from a number of key stakeholders.

  • Building this community will ultimately result in making tribal knowledge reusable, which will generate a lot of value in the mid- and long-term. This will especially benefit two personas: Knowledge Seekers + SMEs (more on that below)

  • It could be that there is already some level of value realization during this stage, but the focus should be on derisking adoption (POV) and measuring engagement through metrics that are leading metrics for business value.

2) Continued Growth + Value Realization (3 months+)

  • After a certain critical mass of knowledge workers is onboarded on Stack Overflow and starts capturing more significant portions of knowledge that are reused over time, this is when Customers will derive significant value for their business.

  • The personas benefitting can be broken down into two main high-level ones:

    • Knowledge Seekers: Will benefit from spending less time searching for information, asking questions, and waiting for answers.

    • SMEs: Will benefit from spending less time answering repeated questions

  • As for time saved per persona, this would vary based on the specific use case the customer is targeting, but to get an initial estimate I would start with following resources:

    • Forrester TEI

      • Knowledge Seeker: According to Forrester, the average time to ask a question is 15min. So knowledge seekers would save up to ~14min/Q if they're able to find an answer on Teams.

      • SME: According to Forrester, the average time it takes to answer a question is 30min. So SMEs will save net 30min on average every time someone else finds an answer on SO4T

    • Knowledge Reuse Calculator linked in this article.

      • This is something we can start tracking during a POV. It's based on TEI assumptions and would give us an indication of how much time employees are getting back through their usage of SO4T.

    • Persona-based Knowledge Reuse Calculator here*

      • *Please note that I just did a quick adaptation of the original knowledge reuse calculator to obtain the time saved per persona, per week. It's hard to quantify the exact numbers of SMEs within the community. To improve this model, we could try to extract the unique number of answerers etc..... But the purpose of this exercise was just to give us a quick indication of the potential value of Stack Overflow for these two personas.

      • Particularly for SMEs, the potential can be huge. They are one of the critical roles for a successful launch, so hopefully this helps to more easily explain the "what's in it for me" to them. If they are in pain answering repeated questions today, my experience is that they will very much welcome a way out.

questions.title: Do we have average customer role time saved to correlate to time spent when establishing a community?
questions.body:
After going through on-boarding, I've regularly heard that overcoming the objection of "time required" to get a instance of SOE/SO4B stood up (either as a full deployment or POV) is consistently brought up.

I've reached out to CS, PMM & the SE org to get a sense of any conservative "time savings" we could leverage on this slide (see image below) but hoping to crowd-source any additional insights from the larger community. Looks like we have some previous Q&A here around Amplitude data showing trends of time spent, but hoping to correlate a time savings on top of this.

So the main question is: Does anyone have any broad correlation for each role's time spent to time savings?

My hope is that having some benchmarks that we typically see (for both a) full deployments or b) POV across both SOE/SO4B) could help to assure the concerned customer/prospect that we know what we're doing and we can deliver exceptional value.

comments.body: Is the instance set up with IP block lists/allow lists? Do the end users have access to the IdP used for authentication on those computers?
And if the white list is in place, then yes, they'd need to be on a VPN that can route them through the associated IP. (This is the question behind my comment question above.)

answers.body: No, they should not need anything special under normal circumstances, because SOE is typically accessible over the public internet. They would need to be able to be authenticated via their corporate Identity Provider, and would also need other means of restriction (like IP whitelist) turned off, which it is by default.

questions.title: Will end users that don't have company computers need a VPN to access SOE? How would they gain access?
questions.body: A management consulting customer has end users who work on-site with clients and do not use company computers. How would they log in to SO? Would they need a VPN in order to do so?

comments.body: @StevenSchoenherr keep in mind that in SOE, the customer is able to edit the messaging in the in-product help on the right-hand side of the Ask Question page. They could probably include details there, if it's that important to them, eg. "Make sure character limit exceeds xx"

@MikiHunt, we've definitely covered this, and it is considered by them to be a perfect secondary measure. The concern is a general end user comes to SO for the first time and attempts to post a question.  They could receive an error message for any number of reasons, and the belief of our Champion is that they won't even bother to figure out why.  They will leave and consider the tool invaluable. cc: @animuson

answers.body:
No, it is not possible to customize these messages in any way.

But at the same time, there's not really any reason they should need to. You mention they'd like to mention the character limit, but that is only one thing of a great many thing that could contribute to losing quality score and seeing that message. It'd be very misleading to point solely to the character limit in that kind of message. It may be the thing that causes it to appear most often, but things as simple as multiple consecutive punctuation marks are also considered "low quality" and could contribute to the post being blocked.

Instead, it sounds like what they really want is for us to be more descriptive in the error message and further explain what components of the post led to it being considered low quality.

But the message is intentionally vague because on public sites, we don't want users to have fine details of what's wrong because they could use them to reverse-engineer the algorithm and bypass it more easily without actually improving their content.

I don't know if we'd be willing to part ways with that concept on Teams sites that are of more private nature. Given anyone can just register a team for free, we'd be giving anyone who knows about the heightened detail in Teams a great advantage and level of insight into the system that we don't want them to have since the algorithm works the same way between both products.

It's also worth noting that on Teams B&B (and Enterprise Private Teams, but not the main site where it defaults to 60), the QualityThreshold defaults to 1. This cannot be changed on Teams B&B so it should still be set to 1. And receiving a quality score <= 1 is exceptionally hard to do.

questions.title: Are error messages on Stack Overflow for Teams configurable?
questions.body:
Is it possible to change the messaging that populates on an error message when asking a question?

comments.body: @GraceNote It always surprised me that suggested synonyms don't populate the "Suggested Edits" review queue. I assume there's a good reason for that, either conceptual or technical, and was wondering if you have any insight?

@MikiHunt Several reasons starting with the fact they were completely different systems designed at different times. Synonyms are in fact older (2010) than suggested edits (2011), so they were built on an older UI design pattern and without any form of queue plans. Suggested edits were built with a queue because they also come at a much higher expected volume (given it's opening the doors to every user), and have to be evaluated more deeply on an individual basis. So presenting them in a queue works for getting that evaluation [...]

@MikiHunt Synonyms, however, don't need that much evaluation - they occupy in full content less than a line of a page each. The Pending Approval page, and all historic variants of it, thus allow you to review every suggested synonym at once, or at least all the ones related to the tag you're looking at. Which lets you handle all of your input at once instead of needing to evaluate them one at a time in a queue. Also, we just don't value synonyms highly. They're a useful tool but not a value point (see: posts vs. comments for similar), so we left it at sufficient tooling.
@GraceNote thanks! I knew you'd have the intel. Appreciate ya!

answers.body:
We don't expose the tag synonym suggestions through the API. And if I want to be honest, I don't think it's a good idea to pursue it, and would instead recommend that Team / Enterprise moderators make good use of the "Pending Approval" list of synonyms that you linked.

The public voting system for tag synonyms was something designed within the constraints of the public Q&A. This is a significantly larger userbase than every client we have and will ever have, and is easily identified by the threshold for voting: users must have a score of at least 5 across answers to the tag and you need at least 4 such users to perform this. This worked in the public Q&A because it was established years after we already had enough people, so getting "4 people who participate in this tag" is drive by and easy enough for users dedicated to non-appointed moderation activity.

In early points in the adoption lifecycle, this is a potentially irksome barrier, due to a myriad of factors:

  • Getting people to vote a lot in the start
  • Getting enough questions for different people to provide answers
  • Getting enough people that you don't need to hound basically the same 4 people from each separate team to handle synonyms in their domain
  • Getting those people to have enough motivation to handle non-appointed moderation activity across the board when it is apparently already a chore for a dedicated moderator to look into the information

While I understand the point brought up about "There's a lot of pages to consider already for moderators, who already have day jobs", I still advise the Pending Approval page for the simple reason that this is the page that action can actually be taken to get it done with. This is a page that contains all of both the necessary information to evaluate decisions on the process, and all of the necessary tools to take action on those decisions.

Creating an API printout of tag synonym suggestions that can be accessed in reports or in an external system may surface the issues faster, but still mean they have to visit the site to get a full picture of the situation. Or, it means extra development time on the customer's end to create the reporting on a thorough enough scale to... replicate a system we already have built.

I would also motion that synonyms are not a system that needs heavy or frequent monitoring. When a new technology or prospect results in a new tag series, maybe it may warrant some extra attention as people find footing, but otherwise parlance and vocabulary tend to settle quickly enough that synonyms could be checked on like, a monthly basis.

Thinking on it - if the issue is there's a lot of disparate pages that need to be reviewed by moderators, then maybe we need to fix the moderator dashboard to address this. On the public Q&A, the moderator dashboard is focused on flag handling because that represents the majority of their job since the community size is large enough to handle the smaller components, along with vote fraud investigation. The other pages like the tag synonym summary lists or duplicate post analysis are just collected on another page as links to individually check. This doesn't line up with the major responsibilities of moderators on intra-organizational Q&A, where seeing things like an overview of "Recently created tags in the last weeks", or "Tag synonym suggestions", or similar might help from a numeric indicator that tells you "There's something to actually look at here". Basically - consider options to make it so that there is a place on-site where moderators can identify that there is something they need to do from a glance, before needing to visit the individual pages to do such things.

questions.title: Is there an API for surfacing tag synonym suggestions?
questions.body:
Is there an API for grabbing the currently suggested tag synonyms (i.e. the ones that have NOT completed a voting cycle yet)?

I've looked at the API objects for tags and tag synonyms, but neither seems to include tag synonym suggestions -- only the synonyms that have been formally configured/accepted. Let me know if these observations are incorrect; it would probably save me a bunch of trouble.

Context

I'm inclined to believe that when a user takes the time to suggest a tag synonym, it'd be rare -- if ever -- that the synonym suggestion actually goes through a complete voting cycle, such as on the public site. As a result, that tag synonym suggestion needs to be reviewed by a moderator/admin. However, I'm not aware of any suggestion notifications that get sent from our product -- again, correct me if I'm mistaken here.

I think the best we have is this report, which seems to exist in all tiers of the product, but requires moderators/admins to remember to check it.

Side note: this adds to an already lengthy list of different reports/views a moderator/admin needs to go to in order to manage a community, when they already have a day job

Even within SO Internal, there are many synonym/merge suggestions that have been sitting in a queue for months and I wasn't aware.

I'm hoping some form of an API could be leveraged to generate notifications or scheduled reports to help customers manage their tags better.

comments.body: As an example, searching SO Internal via the UI (not even using the API) I found only 11 references to "sites.google.com/a/stackoverflow.com" which is our internal wiki. I would not bother with an API-based approach for 11 links.

@Reid Just got off a follow up; they've already extracted SO data and looks like there's about 500 links that need to be mapped/updated, so automation would be necessary. What would be best practice here to help get a script developed to update all those links and then export the modified content back into their instance? An SE request I assume?

answers.body:
I would think that a series of thoughtful API calls would make this relatively easy. Notably the /api/search/advanced endpoint enables a user to search specifically within the body text, where this link would presumably appear; retrieve the question IDs from this search. You'll then need to loop back through Questions (and possibly Answers and / or Posts) using the retrieved IDs against the /api/questions/{id}/edit endpoint to make changes to each post.

Bear in mind that you will need good knowledge of the URL schemes at work in both Box and Sharepoint so you can accurately map old to new. Depending on how many posts are in their environment (and how many of these links there are) it may be easier to use the API to get a list of posts, but make the changes manually, unless the number of links is relatively high.

questions.title: Replacing box links during Sharepoint migration?
questions.body:
A customer of mine (Adenza) had the below question:

  • We are currently going through a Sharepoint migration and need to replace the box links with new Sharepoint links

  • Are there any options or suggestions for doing this automatically/avoid having to manually change each link?

Any ideas here are appreciated!

answers.body:
Like with adding new columns, the first step is making sure a migration has happened that includes a view named exactly vExport<tablename>. So for the RelatedQuestions table, you'll want to deploy something like this:

CREATE OR ALTER VIEW dbo.vExportRelatedQuestions
AS
  SELECT PostId, RelatedPostId, Position, Score
    FROM dbo.RelatedQuestions;

If you want to leave out the Score and only include the first three by position, you can say:

CREATE OR ALTER VIEW dbo.vExportRelatedQuestions
AS
  SELECT PostId, RelatedPostId, Position
    FROM dbo.RelatedQuestions
    WHERE Position <= 3;

You can also use conditional logic to change the output for a given column. For example:

CREATE OR ALTER VIEW dbo.vExportRelatedQuestions
AS
  SELECT PostId, RelatedPostId, 
      Position_Desc = CASE Position 
        WHEN 1 THEN 'The best'
        ELSE 'Not quite the best'
      END
    FROM dbo.RelatedQuestions
    WHERE Position <= 3;

You can see more complex examples in migrations like this one.

In order for the data exposed by the view to get picked up in the weekly SEDE export, you'll also need to add a row to the SEDE table [CO-DESQL01].[Data.StackExchange].dbo.TablesToImport. For example:

INSERT [Data.StackExchange].dbo.TablesToImport(TableName)
  VALUES(N'RelatedQuestions');

The system is fault tolerant so, if the latter happens first, and the export is attempted before the view actually exists, it will simply skip past it. If the view exists before the row is added, even more no harm/no foul.

comments.body: Are you copy-pasting this link into a browser? Because that wouldn't work. /questions/add is only a route when the request method is POST whereas a normal browser request is a GET.
Think I fixed the funky curl request, lmk if it's not working.
@ShreyasNatesan This is about v3 of the API, not v2, but if you ever want a crash course in Postman, I put together a Lessonly: stackoverflowteams.com/c/stack-overflow/questions/22837

answers.body:
Are you simply entering the URL you specified into the browser? That's making a GET request, which is likely why the 404 is being returned—that method requires a POST request.

If you make the POST request in Postman or in curl, it should work (you can run this in your terminal, assuming you have curl installed):

curl -L -X POST 'https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/api/2.3/questions/add?access_token=BVh9KHIMwb56AwUlqFZ1ig))&key=xZa3rZCgn0IoCVkXsjMuGw((' -H 'Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' -d 'title=Title Goes Here' -d 'body=Body Goes Here' -d 'tags=tags-here'

An API call will typically use one of four methods:

  • GET - retrieve data from a server

  • POST - send data to a server

  • PUT - replace existing data on a server

  • DELETE - delete data on a server

When trying to perform an API call to create something, such as the /questions/add endpoint, it most often -- if not always -- requires you to use a POST method. However, if you take that URL and throw it into the address bar of your browser, your browser is simply using a GET method, trying to retrieve data from a server (such as a webpage).

The exception is that a web browser can use other methods when a form and/or button is involved, such as the form and button in the screenshot you shared, where it can trigger a POST method to test the API call for you.

So... the real question: how can you use a POST method with that URL, particularly when your browser is typically going to want to try to render a web page via the GET method?

Aside from picking up a coding/scripting language, like Python or PowerShell, two avenues come to mind:

  • Postman | how to build an API request with Postman

  • cURL | how do I make a POST request using curl?

answers.body:
Focus on the primary way that Stack Overflow for Teams wins against Copilot: Capturing and distributing knowledge from the minds of developers.

Your initial response: 

I’m hearing that a lot of companies are considering Copilot as a way to increase developer productivity. 

It seems like everyone is trying to figure out how GenAI can benefit them. From what I’ve heard, tools like Copilot are great at writing basic code and tasks - things that are necessary but not challenging.   

Then, you ask:

We’ve heard that Copilot can help speed up writing code, saving developers time upfront, but that it does not eliminate the need to consult with senior developers or domain experts to work through logic, debugging, and requirements validation. If Copilot is a success for your team, how do you plan to enable these types of knowledge transfer and collaboration? 

If they aren’t sure: I’m hearing from other customers that they also struggle with this. That’s where Stack Overflow for Teams is helping bridge the gap between stored knowledge available to AI training data sets and the domain-specific or non-code questions that developers encounter during their daily work. SO for Teams also enables cross-functional knowledge collaboration and transfer that Copilot cannot deliver because it’s only available within the IDE. 

If they say Confluence, Jira, or another wiki tool: Those tools are important parts of a software development ecosystem, but can be burdensome when it comes to breaking down silos between teams. Searching through many tickets and long-form documentation for the focused answers you need now can be difficult. SO for Teams works with these tools, and Copilot, as a more natural way for cross-functional and distributed teams to collaborate together. 

Then, you ask:

If Copilot is a success for you and developers now have more time, do you think your developers will spend more time documenting their projects?

The expected answer is no. Developers don’t like to write documentation and having more time means they’ll spend it on more complex tasks, not documenting their work.

If answer is no: That’s what I’ve heard from other clients too. They're still struggling with the gap between brain-stored and documentation-stored knowledge too. 

What I’m hearing them say is that they are looking at Stack Overflow for Teams as that last mile connection between knowledge stored and knowledge delivered or between general and domain specific knowledge. Because it’s easy and natural for a developer to ask or answer a question for a colleague rather than write documentation. 

How are you thinking about solving for that gap? Do you think Copilot can do that for you?

If the answer is yes:

That’s awesome—and unusual! Where do you think they’ll be doing that documentation? Is that documentation accessible to other teams such as QA, Ops, Security, and product management/marketing? How has discovery been there, historically?

**
Then, you ask:**

I have one other question about Copilot for you and then we can move on. With your developers being free to work on more complex challenges, how are you thinking about distributing those new learnings to the rest of the org? 

I ask because I’m hearing that Copilot is great at enabling individual developers but it doesn’t really do anything to capture or distribute the new approaches that those developers come up with. It’s almost like we’re keeping developers in their silos with Copilot and not connecting them to the network of peers internally.

How are you thinking about reusing the knowledge from these developers and making sure folks aren’t recreating the wheel? Do you think Copilot can do that for you? 

Resources:

  • GitHub Copilot Battlecard

  • See how Copilot works (webinar on Copilot that shows how it helps developers)

  • Customer-facing slides

  • AI-assisted tools Educast

  • More basic answers and guidance

Other questions you can use to understand their thought process around AI:

  • What are some of the challenges your companies are trying to overcome? Are there problems that you hope AI/ML and GenAI can help to solve?

  • Are you currently using AI-assisted developer tools at your company? If so, are you replacing or augmenting existing development workflows with these new tools?

  • How do you learn about new AI/ML and GenAI developer tools? 

  • What factors do you consider when evaluating new AI/ML and GenAI developer tools?

  • Do you have any security concerns around GenAI/AI developer tools?  If so, what are your top security concerns regardingwhen it comes to AI/ML and GenAI?

  • What business case are you being asked to make to justify new AI/ML or GenAI tools?

  • What metrics or measurements do you use when evaluating AI/ML new tools?

questions.title: My customer said they are exploring GitHub Copilot; what can I do to position SO for Teams? (Advanced version)
questions.body:
My client mentioned they are using or evaluating GitHub Copilot for their developers. 

What should I say?

comments.body: I might note that the two products are often (usually?) involved in two completely different workflows. As mentioned, Copilot is more about when a developer is coding. SO for Teams can help with most of the other parts of a developer's job, including planning, designing, researching, troubleshooting, deploying, etc.
@JonathanKlick some of that is addressed in the "advanced version" of this messaging, in case you missed it: stackoverflowteams.com/c/stack-overflow/questions/23310

@Natalie Hmm... my recommendation would be to have a single question on this topic (following typical SO best practices). Remove the "(simple version)" suffix from the question title and include both the simple and advanced version in the same answer, using header font to distinguish the two. This will help to make sure your intended audience finds a single source of truth and both versions of that truth.

answers.body:
Focus on the primary way that Stack Overflow for Teams wins against Copilot: Capturing and distributing knowledge from the minds of developers.

Question: We are evaluating Copilot, how does Stack Overflow for Teams compare?

  • Answer: Copilot is a tool for writing code and code completion. Stack Overflow for Teams is a platform focused on knowledge sharing and collaboration.

Question: Does Stack Overflow for Teams have any GenAI capabilities?

  • Answer: Stack Overflow is working on AI initiatives to improve developer workflows.

Resources:

  • GitHub Copilot Battlecard

  • See how Copilot works (webinar on Copilot that shows how it helps developers)

  • Customer-facing slides

  • AI-assisted tools Educast

  • More advanced answers and guidance on Copilot

answers.body:
The easiest way to do this is from one of the web vms, and using a tool called redli. redli is like redis-cli, except it's cross-platform and supports tls.

  1. Download redli onto the machine you're working on.
  2. Grab the connection string details from Azure for the Redis instance you want to connect to
  3. Connect to the redis instance. An example of connecting to an instance is below.
./redli --host=redis-qe-channels-b5bs.redis.cache.windows.net --port=6380 --auth=PASSWORD_FROM_AZURE --tls

From that point, you should be able to run commands against the redis instance.

answers.body:
Yes, you can track how many users trigger Any Active Event across all time.

See this report here for Number of Users who Visited, Consumed, Contributed, Asked, Answered.

Let's use JLR as an example. If we filter for company_ticker = jlr, 647 users triggered an event, meaning there are 647 Total Registered Users.

Some caveats:

  • This method is most applicable for newer deployments, as it does not exclude deleted users. Also, Amplitude is not able to track this for customer instances that were deployed before Amplitude was implemented

  • The actual Total Registered User count may be higher, if users have cookies blocked

comments.body: I think automated tag management / reviews is part of Content Health v2 CC @KaraTully

I'll add here that we also encourage Teams Moderators to review new tags ~1x/wk (adjusting to less frequently, depending on the rate new tags are created in their community). Since part of their role is helping to establish Community Norms, they'll make it easier on themselves to correct behavior if they're actively reaching out to users who have created a potentially unnecessary tags

answers.body:
We don't currently have a "tag review" system. Could make one but at least for now there isn't such.

There is an automation system where we do purge unused tags, which is best covered in this question. Other than that, the tags page is the system designed for reviewing tags. It can be sorted by Newest if you're looking into newly created tags, or it can be sorted by Popular and then sifted to the end to review tags that are not really being used. At a glance, you'll be able to see the number of posts that are using the tag, and whether or not a subject matter expert has been assigned (as there will be no "Manage subject matter experts" link without them).

That said, from a community management perspective... I would recommend suggesting that this isn't a major concern, for two reasons.

  • Tagging is an organic process that develops as the system is used long term. The tag culling process takes 6 months because it's an ample time to ensure that, really, no one is actually using the tag. Tags that random users create on a whim tend to fall for this because they only created it on the spot, and if no one else bothers to use it then it'll get purged softly.
  • You can drastically reduce the overhead of needing to review tags if you teach your userbase to tag with the intent of getting answers. I say this a lot, but the genuine purpose of tags isn't "to categorize content", it's "to get your question answered". That's why it's required before you can even post the question. You can read a deeper level treatise from me on the subject here but in summation, remind users that it's in their best interest to use tags that already exist because no one can subscribe to a tag before it exists, thus drastically weakening its ability to get answered. Creating a new tag makes sense if you're the first person asking about a brand new project or company direction, but if you're not, the first stop should be to figure out what existing tag helps surface the question to the people who will actually give you an answer. Encourage users to approach their questions this way and it should reduce new tag creation woes.

This isn't ultimately going to solve poor tags ever being generated, but it should reduce it to a degree that an API generated dig up of tag usage every few months will suffice to help clean up underused or unusued tags. Or just using the Tags page sorted by popularity, if one wants to view it directly in-site.

RE tags with no SMEs assigned:

For big communities, it can make sense to restrict tag creation, at least during launch or a POV. You want to avoid having hundreds or thousands of users with the ability to create tags that have no SMEs watching them.

As we're targeting a high percentage of answered questions, as well as a low median time to answer, having SMEs subscribed to tags is crucial. However, they won't be notified of questions with new tags, because nobody is subscribed to those.

We can use a Tagging Workshop to help key community stakeholders and SMEs think about what tags they need for first couple months worth of adoption. That v1 list of tags can and should be iterated as time passes. There should also be a process on the customer side to allow users to suggest new tags to be added (albeit we don't support such an approval workflow inside the product).

questions.title: Do tags without much content (or an SME linked) get proactively pushed to be reviewed?
questions.body:
After searching SOI for this type of question, I didn't see anything so am posting here to get ideas/feedback from the team. A question came up where the concern was raised that, "if anyone can create a tag, how do we effectively monitor that the tag is 1) linked to meaningful content & 2) has appropriate SMEs linked?"

I answered with simple filtering on the tag page to "newest" to review those that don't have a description, relevant content linked and/or SME attached. However, the question remains: can the product proactively serve up any tags without much content (or an SME linked) to be reviewed?

After perusing our APIs (I'm still only 1.5 months on the job as an SE), I looks like we have API capabilities to monitor/track the creation of new tags (and whether or not they're linked to content and/or SMEs?), but I'm not seeing a way to do this in the product aside from filtering tags to "newest."

I ask only because this still seems like a manual process that is painful/arduous to complete (whether or not they use our API or not). Has anyone run into this objection before when launching a POV or doing a full deploy? Are there any recommendations or workarounds anyone could share (e.g., improved filtering capabilities)?

comments.body: Thank you @animuson!

@AmandaCheel -- based on your request, the two most useful endpoints will be /badges/recipients and /badges/{ids}/recipients. The former will be if the customer wants to a get pseudo-stream of new badge awards. The latter will be if the customer wants to get a thorough list of who has been awarded each kind of badge.

answers.body:
Badges haven't yet been added to API v3, but there are several routes for retrieving all badges on the site and their recipients in API v2:

  • badges - Get all badges on the site, in alphabetical order.
  • badges/{ids} - Get the badges identified by ids.
  • badges/name - Get all non-tagged-based badges in alphabetical order.
  • badges/recipients - Get badges recently awarded on the site.
  • badges/{ids}/recipients - Get the recent recipients of the given badges.
  • badges/tags - Get all tagged-based badges in alphabetical order.

answers.body:
If it's hosted elsewhere, we support normal markdown image syntax.

Example of markdown syntax to simply display a picture:

![enter image description here](https://stackoverflowteams.com/c/stack-overflow/images/s/081485d6-d3b5-4724-8d4c-299deffa6779.png)

Example with embedded URL (clickable picture):

[![enter image description here](https://stackoverflowteams.com/c/stack-overflow/images/s/081485d6-d3b5-4724-8d4c-299deffa6779.png)](https://stackoverflowteams.com/c/stack-overflow/images/s/081485d6-d3b5-4724-8d4c-299deffa6779.png)

But haven't found a workaround for images that are embedded without being uploaded either to our servers or an external one.

We don't support embedding image data into a post in this way, even for significantly smaller images that would fit within the character count. You'll need to have a link to an image, or the image file itself that can be uploaded to the team directly.

If you're copying images out of Google Docs or some other program that forces Base64 images upon you, there's probably a better way to get the image. If there are a number of images in a Google Doc, downloading the document as a "web page" so that all the images are in a ZIP file is probably most efficient, as you'll have all the images already in one place on your hard drive.

If you really are just stuck with Base64 image data and no way to otherwise retrieve the image, you'll need to use a simple tool like this JavaScript converter to turn it back into an image that you can then upload.

comments.body: For Enterprise (and Managed Business), we got some SLAs linked from here stackoverflowteams.com/c/stack-overflow/a/12442/47 - not sure if priority support entails more than a reply within the given time frame.
@MichaelStum Thanks! Yeah, trying to figure out what specifically "priority support" means and who does/doesn't have it so the SE teaching materials are correct. :)

The priority customer support thing was specific to when we did Intercom support. When customers chatted with us, they'd be marked as "high priority" there. It was mostly meaningless since we were rarely handling more than one customer that we needed to prioritize one over the other. But we no longer do Intercom chat support, and never did on Enterprise. In Freshdesk, there is a separate category for Enterprise but all tiers of Teams are clumped into one category with no differentiation. So it seems to be an artifact of past systems?

Thanks! This seems to make sense—originally was trying to sort out if the dedicated CSM impacted support as well, seems like the answer is no. cc @AlexaMontelibano , whose question prompted this conversation. :)

answers.body:
Currently, priority support seems to describe how we handle incoming support requests from multiple customers across tiers. It is is not a separate support "product," although in the past there used to be upgraded support packages available. (Our Business and Enterprise customers both have the best support we offer, there's no upgrade option to premium support.)

Business support tickets have priority over tickets and support requests coming in from Free and Basic customers, based on incident severity.

Managed Business customers have a 99.5% uptime SLA, while self-serve customers do not (so even within the Business tier, managed customers have an advantage). The ARR thresholds for Business are about whether or not they have a dedicated CSM, and do not have any impact on their support level afaik.

Enterprise customers have priority over Business, based on incident severity. Enterprise customers also have the 99.5% SLA.

articles.title: SOE Code Signing Web Service 2023
articles.body:
Overview

Jira: TEAMS-9727

Slack Threads:

  • https://stackexchange.slack.com/archives/C028BJVQW1L/p1684507261650849
  • https://stackexchange.slack.com/archives/C231F95Q8/p1685027612285489
  • https://stackexchange.slack.com/archives/C231F95Q8/p1686076868426209

TL;DR: EV Code Signing certificates can no longer be just PFX files, they MUST be stored in a HSM or Security Token. This is not just a Digicert thing, other EV Code Signing certificate vendors do the same.

So, Digicert sent us a Hardware Token that needs to be plugged into the machine that does the code signing. The token is a Thales SafeNet eToken 5110, and it installs a driver/agent onto the machine.

The signing Web Service

We created a Web Service (See PR #16429) which provides an interface to the signing process (basically just automation around signtool.exe - see Background at the bottom of this article).

This is used by ExtractAndSignSetup.ps1 to sign the PowerShell scripts during the build process.

The web service provides an endpoint, /sign which accepts a form with a file and will return the signed file, or an error code. You can check the Service README for more information.

Example Usage

var targetUrl = "http://ny-rdp01.ds.stackexchange.com:12400/sign";
var filename = @"C:\BuildAgent\work\cc0568694867822b\setup\Common\StackOverflowEnterprise\Utilities.ps1";

var fileContent = new ByteArrayContent(System.IO.File.ReadAllBytes(filename));
fileContent.Headers.ContentType = new MediaTypeHeaderValue("application/octet-stream");

var multipartFormContent = new MultipartFormDataContent();
// Preserving the original filename is important since signtool.exe cares about the extension
multipartFormContent.Add(fileContent, name: "file", fileName: Path.GetFileName(filename));

var client = new HttpClient();
var result = await client.PostAsync(targetUrl, multipartFormContent);
var rc = await result.Content.ReadAsStringAsync();
rc.Dump(); // LINQPad
result.Dump();

Web Service Deployment Information

The service must be deployed on the machine with the DigiCert USB Hardware token, which in our case is NY-RDP01.

  • Service is deployed in C:\SOE Code Signing\StackOverflowCodeSigningService
  • Service Logs are in C:\SOE Code Signing\CodeSignLogs (there is log rotation/retention)
  • Service uses Windows Temp Directory and also C:\SOE Code Signing\CodeSignCache
    • (Both Logs and Cache are safe to delete if ever needed)
  • Windows Service is called StackOverflowCodeSigningService and set to Automatic (Delayed Start) in case the token has a service that also wants to start automatically
  • Service listens on HTTP Port 12400 and has no other network dependencies, apart from being reachable from build environments
    • When we need to build from GHA, we need to look at private runners.
  • Source code lives in the StackEng/StackOverflow repository
  • Service is compiled and packaged via a GitHub Actions workflow, but it's deployed manually by unzipping the Nuget Package downloaded from Cloudsmith
  • Prod Binaries live in Cloudsmith, StackOverflowCodeSigningService in nuget-software

You can make a GET Request or open http://ny-rdp01.ds.stackexchange.com:12400/ in a browser to see if the service is up and running.

// GET http://ny-rdp01.ds.stackexchange.com:12400/
{"serviceName":"Stack Overflow Code Signing Service","version":"2023.620.12016.13"}

Caching

It takes several seconds to sign a file, and in total it took 120 seconds to sign all 34 files that were in the installer at time of writing. To speed up the process and also reduce the reliance on the actual token if we're signing the same files over and over again, we cache the signed files on the machine. They are stored in C:\SOE Code Signing\CodeSignCache, which is the FileCacheLocation in appSettings.json.

If we want to wipe that cache for whatever reason to re-sign all files, it's possible to either manually delete the contents of that folder, or make an HTTP POST call to http://ny-rdp01.ds.stackexchange.com:12400/clear-cache

FAQ

Is there a dev environment?

No. There's only one code signing certificate and only one hardware token. That said, because results are cached based on the content of the input file, feel free to send dev scripts/scripts from your local branch to it if you need them signed.

And if you do somehow mess something up, just clear the cache.

I'm connected through RDP, and cannot access the token

For some reason, the Thales client software doesn't find USB devices when connected via RDP. You will need to have access to connect via KVM. And yes, interacting with the mouse pointer is an absolute nightmare, and no, it's not better in the Java client either.

I locked myself out of the token because of too many authentication failures :(

This can happen if you don't get the command line to signtool.exe correct. There are two password: The Token Password and the Administrator Password. If you mistype the Token Password too many times, you need to use the Administrator Password to reset the Token Password.

If you mistype the Administrator Password too many times, the token will be bricked, so be extra careful here

You can use the SafeNet Authentication Client Tools. Select "Advanced View" on the start screen, then "Set Token Password". You will be asked for the Administrator Password and then you can set a new token password, which will unlock the token.

Do not use the "Unlock Token" option right next to it, that's some challenge/response stuff that doesn't really apply.

Make sure to update secret server with the new Token Password

If this is a physical object in the data center, how will the datacenter move affect this?

Unknown at this time.

Maybe Azure's Code Signing Service will be ready by then, but we'll figure out that option when we get there.

Why do we even need Code Signing at all?

For On-Premises SOE. Specifically, our Installer Scripts are all PowerShell scripts, and the default execution policy on Windows server is RemoteSigned.

On-Premises customers would have to Set-ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted in order to run our installer, and with some customers, that's not getting approved by their InfoSec teams. So that's why we sign the PowerShell scripts.

With the sunsetting on SOE On-Prem, this becomes a lesser issue, however, we are still committed until Mid-2025 and thus need a solution in place.

Which signtool.exe is being used?

There are many different versions of signtool.exe, some ship with Visual Studio, .NET SDKs, or the Windows SDK. I successfully used the signtool.exe with version 10.0.14340.1000 which has a digital signature from 2016-07-16 11:49 AM, and the SHA-256 of the file is bd45f546cf4e25c800518c26fca0de58aee240f59bc814e0cf4d84ceb0632e8b.

There are newer versions, and I don't know if there's a meaningful difference, but this one worked. The Web Service bundles that version of signtool.exe so that we're not reliant on whatever is on the machine.

What is the expected Thumbprint / Public Key?

The public key is checked into source control. The Thumbprint is 4CEA46FCF3B5B33B9936F701C080FFCD009712E2.

[Subject]
CN="Stack Exchange, Inc.", O="Stack Exchange, Inc.", L=New York, S=New York, C=US

[Issuer]
CN=DigiCert Trusted G4 Code Signing RSA4096 SHA384 2021 CA1, O="DigiCert, Inc.", C=US

[Serial Number]
07C0183A5EC0C49E8182971DF07E0E51

[Not Before]
5/24/2023 5:00:00 PM

[Not After]
6/1/2026 4:59:59 PM

[Thumbprint]
4CEA46FCF3B5B33B9936F701C080FFCD009712E2

We do use a TimeStamp server as well, which is http://timestamp.digicert.com. The Thumbprint/Certificate of the TimeStamper is not under our control and might vary.

Background: What does the Web Service actually do?

The signing process

There is a tool, DigiCertUtil.exe that can be used to manually sign a file. However, manually signing stuff is stupid. So instead, someone found out a way to automate it.

I had to enable "Enable single login for PKCS#11" for this to work. This is a one-time change, so this hardware token should be good now.

This uses Microsoft's signtool.exe, and it doesn't seem that the Powershell Set-AuthenticodeSignature cmdlet can be used.

The idea is to do this:

signtool.exe sign /tr http://timestamp.digicert.com /td sha256 /fd sha256 /f "EnterpriseSigning2023.cer" /csp "eToken Base Cryptographic Provider" /k "[{{TOKENPASSWORDHERE}}]=p11#xxxxxxxxxxx" FileToSign.ps1

Where EnterpriseSigning2023.cer is the exported (public key) certificate, p11#... is the Container Name, and the TOKENPASSWORDHERE is the actual Token Password, which can be retrieved from Secret Server.

Important: Do NOT use the Token Administrator Password. Misuse of the Administrator Password can brick the entire hardware token.

articles.title: Project SAIL - WeAreDevelopers event
articles.body:
Sharing high-level information for WeAreDevelopers (WAD) activities in July 2023.

Reach out to Michael Tien if you have any questions.

Dates: July 26-July 28, 2023

Location: Berlin, Germany

Before the conference: What we're doing

Email campaigns and social posts to:

  1. drive attendance to Prashanth's keynote and fireside chat

  2. secure at least 10 meetings with key prospects

  3. drive qualified prospects to our booth

Promote Stack Overflow Labs to start building awareness and excitement for our evolution.

High-level sales enablement training on what we're launching, when, and what to tell customers/prospects.

Conference content: What we're doing

Brand Design is building videos for the keynote that show six new experiences. They are building these videos from Figma designs or prototypes.

The workshop is a talk by a few Stack Overflow people, sharing our journey in building AI.

At the conference: What we're doing

July 26 - Executive Dinner

July 27 - Main Stage Keynote (Prashanth) - 30 minutes

Talk will be recorded and posted on WeAreDevelopers site and their YouTube channel

Date TBD - Fireside Chat (Prashanth & guest)

Date TBD - Workshop

July 27-28 - Exhibition booth

After the conference: What we're doing

Posting the videos from the keynote to Stack Overflow Labs. May also include additional video demos (if available).

Refresher sales enablement training on what we launched, when, and what to tell customers/prospects.

Releasing an Experiment Roadmap that shows estimates for when we'll be in Alpha, Beta, and General Availability stages.

Email campaigns and social posts to promote Stack Overflow Labs and our new features/products.
