articles.title: Connectivity is live on SO Internal
articles.body:
Connectivity Overview

Connectivity is a new Dashboard feature in Stack Overflow for Teams Enterprise that leverages user attributes (role and department) to surface meaningful insights into how knowledge flows across an organization. Customers can get visibility into Connections made across the organization with Connectivity metrics and data visualization through a new chord chart.

The goal of Connectivity is to help organizations 1) understand how Teams enables knowledge sharing and collaboration and 2) provide insights to continue to break down knowledge silos by:

  • Reporting on Connection metrics and establishing benchmarks on how knowledge is shared across an org

  • Visualizing how cross-functional teams engage and how often answers come from other departments

  • Identifying opportunities to engage less active departments and roles

Product and plans

Stack Overflow for Teams

SO Internal  ✅- now available!

Free ❌

Basic ❌

Business ❌

Enterprise ✅-available in the 2023.2 release in FY24 Q2

Key objectives

  • Capture, store, and manage new user attributes at scale (role, department)

  • Provide users with clear and impactful data visualizations and metrics that demonstrate how knowledge flows across the organization

  • Increase engagement and grow MAUs

Benefits

As mentioned, Connectivity helps organizations understand how knowledge flows acros the organization. The feature can be useful for different roles across Teams.

Connectivity helps Teams admins and community managers:

  • better understand which roles and teams are actively using Teams.

  • determine where more outreach or action may be needed to encourage less active roles and departments to begin using Teams.

  • deliver a more informed knowledge-sharing strategy.

  • prove value and ROI of Teams to stakeholders.

Connectivity helps Teams users:

  • better understand where their colleagues work.

  • realize their best answers may be coming from adjacent departments.

  • instill trust in provided answers by users who may not yet be recognized as SMEs.

User Experience and Customer Actions

Phase 1: SAML updates

In April and May 2023, we released SAML authentication updates that add two new fields to allow Teams admins to optionally capture additional user details (job title and department) from their IdP and display those fields in the user’s profile. To take advantage of the new fields and future improved metrics from this data, Teams admins need to enable this setting and Teams users need to log in to the platform to re-authenticate through their IdP.

Actions for CSMs

  • Talk to your customers about this important step in enabling Connectivity.

  • Share our SAML Comms Kit for admins and community managers with customers to promote these updates with their internal teams and encourage users to log in to Teams to trigger the updates.

*Future updates will include a csv upload option for admins to manually add this data. Details coming soon.

Phase 2: Connectivity

Access Connectivity by going to the Dashboard and selecting the “Connectivity” tab at the top next to “Overview.” Here, users can see Connection metrics and data visualization through a chord chart or table. Data visualization can be filtered by top departments or all departments.

A Connection occurs when a question is answered. All answers will be registered as a connection, including:

  • Accepted answers

  • Unaccepted answers

  • Answers given by the same user who asked the question

In future iterations, we will consider enabling Connections for other features in Teams like Communities, User Groups, and Tags.

Testing and Feedback

While Connectivity is being released to Enterprise plans only, we’ve released the feature to SO Internal for testing and feedback. The initial testing period for SO Internal will be until July 11, 2023 to help inform our work on the 2023.2 release. Any feedback received after this date will be will be considered for the following release.

Here’s how you can help:

Jump into Connectivity on SO Internal and let us know what you think. We’re looking for feedback on

  • Usability issues

  • Actions or guidance

  • Data questions on current user attributes and what we could use in the future

  • Feature ideas for future iterations

Please send your feedback to the CoGro pod on Slack at #connectivity-feedback.

Resources

Connectivity in Teams, Product Report in SO Internal

Teams Community Growth, Connectivity, Initiative Strategy

Delivered by: Teams Community Growth Pod

PM: Colby Smythe

PMM: Carrie Koos

articles.title: How to confirm MSTeams works in a specific Teams environment
articles.body:
To confirm our MSTeams integration is working as expected for FB&B teams you can follow these steps:

  1. First you'll need an MS Teams instance to test on. To create a free MS Teams instance you'll need a Microsoft 365 developer account that's different than your work email. To create a developer account follow these steps:

    1. Go to: https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/dev-program and click Join now

    2. Login with a Microsoft account (you can use your personal account) and it'll ask you to setup your developer profile which you should fill out however you want and click Next

    3. Continue setting up your developer account until you see the confirmation screen:

    4. On your developer profile page click the Set up E5 subscription link

    5. Choose to setup an Instant Sandbox as described here. Select East US as your data center and provide an Admin username and Admin password, and then choose Continue.

      1. This will create an Azure subscription for you with its own domain name.

      2. So your admin username will look something like this: <user-name>@<domain>.onmicrosoft.com

        In my case I got: admin@0tz2r.onmicrosoft.com

      3. Make sure to save your username and password somewhere safe

      4. You'll also need a valid cellphone to validate your subscription

    6. Now your developer account has been created and you have a free azure subscription with your own MS Teams instance!

  2. If your environment has a reverse proxy for integrations (all Teams environments in Azure do) then you need to confirm that the environment you're testing knows about it. That's configured through the Developer.IntegrationsReverseProxyDomain site setting.

    1. In my case, since I'm testing on Dev, I updated my value to : integrations.stackoverflowteams.dev

    2. If you don't have a reverse proxy or want to bypass it you can blank out this setting and MS Teams will directly hit your app.

    3. If you're testing a local environment, you need some way for MS Teams to be able to send http requests to your machine. We have an amazing guide on how to do that using ngrok here: https://stackoverflowteams.com/c/stack-overflow/a/6674/554

  3. Now we will create a new MS Teams app that is a copy of our prod app to test in our MS Teams instance we created in the previous step. And we will configure the Teams environment we're testing to use this new MS Teams app. If you're testing in prod you would skip this step because prod has an MS Teams app that's published to the marketplace and it's configured to be used on stackoverflowteams.com already. To create a new MS Teams app for testing follow these steps:

    1. Go to: https://teams.microsoft.com/ and login with your admin user that you created as part of your E5 subscriptions. In my case it's admin@0tz2r.onmicrosoft.com

      1. Logins can be funky sometimes so if you get an access error, try again later.

    2. Go to Developer Portal -> Tools -> Bot management . We need to setup a new chat bot for our new MS Teams app

    3. Click the New Bot button and give your bot a name to create a new bot and fill in the following details:

      1. Endpoint address: Tells the bot where to send chat messages

        1. If the environment you're testing on has a reverse proxy for integrations you need to put that as your domain. In my case I'm testing on Dev so I put the following: https://integrations.stackoverflowteams.dev/integrations/microsoft-teams/messages

        2. If you don't have a reverse proxy or want to bypass it you can directly point the bot to your environment instead. E.g: https://stackoverflowteams.dev/integrations/microsoft-teams/messages

        3. If you're testing a local environment, you need some way for MS Teams to be able to send http requests to your machine. We have an amazing guide on how to do that using ngrok here: https://stackoverflowteams.com/c/stack-overflow/a/6674/554

      2. Channels: check the Microsoft Teams box

      3. Client secrets: Generate a new secret here and copy it somewhere safe

    4. Configure the Teams environment you're testing to use this new bot by updating these site settings:

      1. MicrosoftTeams.BotAppId You can find this on the bot management page

      2. MicrosoftTeams.BotAppPassword Set this to the secret you generated earlier

    5. Now we need to create a copy of our MS Teams app in your test MS Teams instance. For this go to /integrations/microsoft-teams/manifest on your environment which will download a zip file containing the MS Teams app.

      I'm testing on dev for this article so my link is: https://stackoverflowteams.dev/integrations/microsoft-teams/manifest

    6. Now's a good time to open the zip file and check out the manifest.json. Make sure the configurableTabs and staticTabs point to the correct domain: reverse proxy if you have it, the environment domain if not, or your local ngrok if you're testing locally.

    7. To upload the app go to **Apps (**in the side bar) -> Manage your apps -> Upload an app -> Upload a custom app and give it your zip file

    8. Click Add to install the custom app

    9. Done! Now you have a copy of our MS Teams app installed on your MS Teams instance.

  4. At this point you should have a test MS Teams app that is a copy of our prod app added to your test MS Teams instance. So you can start testing connectivity.

    1. If you're testing the Prod MS Teams app, login to your MS Teams instance that you're testing on (https://teams.microsoft.com/) with the admin account you created in Step 1 above and install the official prod app instead.

  5. Find the Stack Overflow app in the left sidebar and switch to the Chat tab and type "login" to link your MS Teams account to your SOT account.

    This will link the MS Teams app to the team you're currently logged into.

  6. If you were able to login that means that MS Teams can talk to our environment. Just to be safe try doing a search to confirm that that works too ✔️

  7. Next, lets test if our app can talk to MS Teams by creating a notification. For that switch to the Notifications tab and click Create new notification

  8. Select what the be notified about, I usually select everything for testing just to be safe.

  9. Trigger the event for the webhook. In my case I created a question:

  10. If everything works, you should receive a message from the chat bot like so:

  11. You can also see Slack events that have been triggered for a team by going to /c/<your-team>/developer/services/Webhooks/logs

*This guide is based on recordings from Gervasio: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1c4bLCwWeUZYQDicSBOKGMpNuPllFuPFrPskFsh7dtjA/

articles.title: How to confirm Slack works in a specific Teams environment
articles.body:
To confirm our Slack integration is working as expected for FB&B teams you can follow these steps:

  1. Visit https://app.slack.com/

  2. Once you're logged in with your work email click on Create a new workspace

  3. You should get a code to your email. Put that in to continue.

  4. I prefer to use Slack in the browser for testing because it's easier. So click on the link to use Slack in the web browser. If it asks you if you want to open the Slack desktop app, say No.

    If you want to test on the app, though, you totally can.

  5. Once you're in your workspace for the first time Slack will ask you for a few things like a company/team name, profile name, and users to invite. Put in anything you want and skip until you get your workspace created

  6. Now that you have a Slack workspace to test we need to create a Slack app and configure the environment we're testing to use that new Slack app. To create a new slack app go to: https://api.slack.com/apps

    1. If you're testing on Prod you would skip the next few setup steps because Prod already has an official Slack app that's on the marketplace etc.

    2. Skip to Step 16 if you're testing on an environment that already has a Slack app that you have access to.

  7. Click on Create a new app and select to create it from scratch

  8. Give your app a name (doesn't matter what it is) and select the new workspace you created

  9. Once the app is created you should have access to its credentials which you need to save to site settings in your target environment. I'm testing in the main Dev environment for this article: https://stackoverflowteams.dev

    1. Copy-paste App ID: Slack.GranularPermissionsApp.AppId

    2. Copy-paste Client ID: Slack.GranularPermissionsApp.ClientId

    3. Copy-paste Client Secret: Slack.GranularPermissionsApp.ClientSecret

    4. Base64 encode Signing Secret and then save it to: Slack.GranularPermissionsApp.SigningSecret

      1. It's important that you don't forget to base64 encode the secret before saving it!

  10. If your environment has a reverse proxy for integrations (all Teams environments in Azure do) then you need to confirm that the environment you're testing knows about it. That's configured through the Developer.IntegrationsReverseProxyDomain site setting.

    1. In my case, since I'm testing on Dev, I updated my value to : integrations.stackoverflowteams.dev

    2. If you don't have a reverse proxy or want to bypass it you can blank out this setting and Slack will directly hit your app.

    3. If you're testing a local environment, you need some way for Slack to be able to send http requests to your machine. We have an amazing guide on how to do that using ngrok here: https://stackoverflowteams.com/c/stack-overflow/a/9377/554

  11. Go to /integrations/slack/manifest on your target environment. And copy the json output. In my case it's: https://stackoverflowteams.dev/integrations/slack/manifest

    1. This is a good time to confirm the request_url value is pointing to the correct domain: The reverse proxy if you have it or your environment directly if not. (Or your ngrok endpoint if you're testing locally)

  12. On the page you got the app credentials from, click on App Manifest in the left nav

  13. Switch to the JSON tab on the page that opens and paste in the JSON you got previously and click Save Changes

  14. You might get a warning at the top indicating the target request_url endpoint hasn't been verified. Click to verify it which makes Slack send a specific verification request to the endpoint inrequest_url which then validates it against the Signing Secret you saved earlier.

    1. If the verification is failing you might not have set the Signing Secret correctly in your site settings. Make sure you base64 encode it before saving it. Also in some cases the reverse proxy might not be redirecting the requests correctly which can cause this verification to fail.

  15. So now you have a copy of the Stack Overflow for Teams Slack app created in your Slack workspace (the one you selected initially). The app isn't accessible to any other Slack workspace so no one else can currently install your new Slack app.

    1. If you, optionally, want to install this app on multiple Slack workspaces you need to enable Distribution. If not, skip this step.

    2. To enable Distribution, on the same app manifest screen as the previous step, click on Manage Distribution in the left nav.

    3. On the screen that opens, expand the Remove Hard Coded Information section and check the box.

    4. Now click on Activate Public Distribution

      1. This will allow others who have the url to your slack app to install it.

      2. Your app won't be added to the Slack marketplace or anywhere else. That is handled separately in the 'Submit to App Directory' section which we won't do for our test app.

    5. You can deactivate public distribution at any time from the same screen

  16. Go to: /c/<your-team>/admin/integrations/slack on a team in your environment you want to install your new Slack app on and click Learn more

  17. Click Add to Slack for your team and click Allow on the next security screen.

  18. If everything worked you should see a success message

  19. Switch over to Slack for your test workspace and find your Slack app in the left nav under Apps. Click on it and switch over to the Messages tab

  20. Type /stack connect in the chat which will generate a link. Visit the link and click on Yes, I'm sure! to link your account to that Slack workspace. You should see a Your account has been connected message in chat

  21. Test out some commands like /stack search Test which should return some results to you in Slack. This confirms Slack can reach our app ✔️

  22. Now that we've confirmed Slack can talk to us, we need to confirm we can talk to Slack by sending out alerts to Slack channels from the app.

  23. Start by inviting the Slack app to the channel you want to send messages to by running the following command in that channel /invite @Stack Overflow for Teams-Dev

  24. Go /c/<your-team>/admin/integrations/slack once more and click on the option to create a new Slack notification. Select the options you want and put in your Slack channel where the bot was invited

  25. Trigger one of the events to see if you get messages in Slack. It might take up to 1-2 minutes in some cases for the message to come in.

    In my case I asked a question:

    And got the following message in Slack 30 seconds later: ✔️

  26. You have successfully confirmed Slack works for your environment 🎉

  27. You can also see Slack events that have been triggered for a team by going to /c/<your-team>/developer/services/Webhooks/logs

*This guide is based on recordings from Gervasio: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1c4bLCwWeUZYQDicSBOKGMpNuPllFuPFrPskFsh7dtjA/

articles.title: How to confirm Jira works in a specific Teams environment
articles.body:
To confirm our Jira integration is working as expected for FB&B teams you can follow these steps:

  1. First you'll need your own Jira environment. To create a free one (Note: Jira will destroy it after 30 days of inactivity) go to: https://www.atlassian.com/software and click the Try now button in the top right

  3. Under Jira Software click Try cloud

  4. Sign up / Login with any email you have. I clicked on the Google login and used my regular work email. Once authenticated it should ask you to enter your desired slug for your Jira environment. Fill that out and click Agree

  5. After a bit of initialization you should have access to your Jira environment at https://<your-slug>.atlassian.net/

  6. If your Teams environment has a reverse proxy for integrations (all Teams environments in Azure do) then you need to confirm that the environment you're testing knows about it. That's configured through the Developer.IntegrationsReverseProxyDomain site setting.

    1. In my case, since I'm testing on Dev, I updated my value to : integrations.stackoverflowteams.dev

    2. If you don't have a reverse proxy or want to bypass it you can blank out this setting and Jira will directly hit your app.

    3. If you're testing a local environment, you need some way for Jira to be able to send http requests to your machine. We have an amazing guide on how to do that using ngrok here: https://stackoverflowteams.com/c/stack-overflow/a/7066/554

  7. Now we need to publish a new version of our Jira app for testing. If you're testing the prod Teams environment's Jira app you can skip this part and directly install the official production Jira app in your Jira workspace. To publish a new Jira app for testing:

    • All Jira apps need to have a unique app key which we configure through the Jira.AppDescriptorKey site setting. Update this setting in your environment to a new value to make sure you have a unique key for your test app. The format doesn't matter but you can use the existing format to create your own unique key.

      • If you forget to make this change or you choose a key that's already taken you'll get a "App key must be unique" error in the next step

    • Go to https://marketplace.atlassian.com/ , make sure you're logged in, click on your profile photo in the top right and click Publish a new app

    • Select any Vendor (as Jira calls it) you want.

      • If you don't have a Vendor you'll need to create one which you can do by clicking on the Register your organization and contact details. link. Only the Name and Email fields are required so fill those out and save it.

    • Select the Provide a URL to your artifact (.jar, .obr, .jwb or JSON descriptor) option and click Enter url and point it to: /integrations/jira/app-descriptor for your environment.

      • If the environment you're testing has an integrations reverse proxy you'd use that host name. In my case I'm testing on Dev so I do have a reverse proxy so I used this url: https://integrations.stackoverflowteams.dev/integrations/jira/app-descriptor

      • If you don't have a reverse proxy or want to bypass it, use your environments host name directly.

      • If you're testing locally use your ngrok host name as mentioned above.

    • A few more options will popup. Give your app a name that makes sense to you.

    • Under Compatibility add Jira Cloud compatibility and check the box next to Compatible with Jira Software

    • Click Save as private to create your new Jira app

  8. Next you'll need to install the Jira app on the new Jira workspace you created in step 1 (If testing on prod simply install the official prod app onto your Jira workspace and skip this step):

    1. If you created your own Jira test app as described above go to https://marketplace.atlassian.com/manage/apps and click on your app.

    2. Switch to the Private listings tab and find the installation URL link. Copy that link to your clipboard.

    3. Go to your Jira workspace and go to Apps -> Manage your apps in the top bar

    4. On the page that opens click on Settings and check both boxes on the popup that opens to enable private listings & developer settings:

      The Enable development mode option isn't really required to be checked but I do it anyway.

    5. Click on Upload app and give it the private listing url you copied earlier

    6. The app should be installed on your Jira environment now ✔️

  9. Now you should have a test Jira environment with an installed Stack Overflow for Teams Jira app. Go to the Get started page for the app (It might open it automatically for you after installing).

    1. The link is available on Manage your apps page:

    2. If testing the prod app, there should be a Get started link on the app's page in the marketplace after installing it.

  10. On the Get started page click Connect with Stack Overflow

    If this page isn't loading and you get an error from Jira, there are two main causes:

    1. The Jira JS library integrity checksum isn't correct in this site setting: Jira.JavaScriptIntegrityChecksum

      This can easily be confirmed by opening the developer console in your browser (F12) and checking if you see an error in the console around integrity checks.

      The easiest fix is to blank out this site setting (not remove) which will disable the checksum check. But if you want to actually put the checksum in there you can check out this answer.

    2. The reverse proxy isn't working correctly. Check out this article to confirm it's working properly: How to confirm the Integrations Reverse Proxy works in a specific Teams environment

  11. A webpage inside your Teams environment should open asking you which team you want to install Jira on which you should select. Don't forget to check the agreement box. If all goes well Jira should be installed and configured now!

  12. To test if Jira is working, create a Project in your Jira workspace and create a test ticket. You should see a Similar questions link in the right side of the page that you can click on

  13. If you can see questions from your Team that means Jira can talk to our app ✔️

  14. Now we need to confirm if our app can talk to Jira. For that we need to test our Jira OneBox feature. This feature creates a Jira card preview in posts when you paste a link to a Jira card. To test this go to the Ask a question page on your team and paste in a link to a Jira ticket from your test Jira project. If Jira OneBox'ing is working you should see a preview of the ticket get created:

    Make sure you're not editing the post in markdown mode as I believe OneBox'ing doesn't happen in that mode.

  15. You can also see Jira events that have been triggered for a team by going to /c/<your-team>/developer/services/Onebox%20Fetch%20Queue/logs

*This guide is based on recordings from Gervasio: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1c4bLCwWeUZYQDicSBOKGMpNuPllFuPFrPskFsh7dtjA/

articles.title: How to confirm the Integrations Reverse Proxy works in a specific Teams environment
articles.body:
Introduction

When we switched teams over from stackoverflow.com to stackoverflowteams.com in December 2022 we decided to point all integrations to a reverse proxy to decouple the user facing domain from the integrations domain:

  • Prod: https://integrations.stackoverflowteams.com

  • Dev: https://integrations.stackoverflowteams.dev *requires full-tunnel vpn

  • Ephemeral environments: https://integrations.<env>-dev.stackoverflowteams.dev *requires full-tunnel vpn

    • Example: https://integrations.qe-dev.stackoverflowteams.dev

These endpoints do two things:

  1. All requests made to it should 307 redirect to the corresponding main app.

    • E.g.https://integrations.stackoverflowteams.com should 307 to https://stackoverflowteams.com

  2. Requests made to the path /integrations/embedded/jira/* should not 307 and should instead directly pass on the request to the main app and replace the host header with the app's host domain.

    • This is because we show some embedded pages in Jira which don't work with 307 redirects. So those need to work directly without any redirects

How to Test

Utilize the powershell script below to test your reverse proxy. Make sure to change the $ReverseProxyUrl and $MainAppUrl variables to match the environment you are testing.

$ReverseProxyUrl = "https://integrations.stackoverflowteams.com"
$MainAppUrl = "https://stackoverflowteams.com"

#Enable TLS 1.2
[System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol = [System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol -bor [System.Net.SecurityProtocolType]::Tls12

#Confirm the reverse proxy 307's
$result = try{ Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "$ReverseProxyUrl" -Method "GET" -MaximumRedirection 0 } catch { $_.Exception.Response }
if ($result.StatusCode -eq 307) {
    if ($result.Headers.Location -like $($MainAppUrl + "*")) {
        Write-Host -ForegroundColor green "Check 1: Reverse proxy correctly 307's"
    } else {
        Write-Host -ForegroundColor yellow "Check 1: Reverse proxy correctly 307'd but the redirect location: $($result.Headers.Location) didn't match the expected $MainAppUrl"
    }
} else {
    Write-Host -ForegroundColor red "Check 1: Calls to $ReverseProxyUrl are supposed to redirect with a 307 to the main app. Received $([int]$result.StatusCode) instead."
}

#Confirm the special rule for Jira is implemented 
$result = $null
$jiraTestUrl = $ReverseProxyUrl + "/integrations/embedded/jira/path-that-doesnt-exist"
$result = try { Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "$jiraTestUrl" -Method "GET" -MaximumRedirection 0 } catch { $_.Exception.Response }
if ($result.StatusCode -ne 307) {
    if ($result.StatusCode -eq 404) {
        Write-Host -ForegroundColor green "Check 2: Special routing rule for Jira is in place"
    } else {
        Write-Host -ForegroundColor yellow "Check 2: Special routing rule for Jira seems to be working but we were expecting a 404 response from $jiraTestUrl but got $([int]$result.StatusCode) instead. Is the app working as expected?"
    }
} else {
    Write-Host -ForegroundColor red "Check 2: Special routing rule for Jira is missing"
    Write-Host -ForegroundColor red "    Calls to $jiraTestUrl return a 307 which is incorrect."
    Write-Host -ForegroundColor red "    Jira is special such that all requests that have the path '/integrations/embedded/jira/*' need to be `
    routed directly to the target VM's and have the host header replaced with the main app one: $MainAppUrl"
}

If everything is working as expected you should see an output like this:

*This guide is based on recordings from Gervasio: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1c4bLCwWeUZYQDicSBOKGMpNuPllFuPFrPskFsh7dtjA/

articles.title: Data Team Data Sources
articles.body:
Welcome to the List of Data Sources!

This is a curated list of the data sources we currently load and the sources that are currently being evaluated for approval to be loaded in the future. This should help you find answers to basic questions about what data exists, how to get access to it, how often it is loaded, and what is in each security group.

If you don't see a data source listed below that you would like to use, please follow this guide for requesting a new data source.

For the procedure to request access to an existing data source, see How can I gain access to Snowflake?

Current Data Sources

HAProxy Traffic Logs

Type Update Frequency Ingestion Pattern Approver
1st Party (NY-LOGSQL02.TrafficLogs) Hourly Azure Data Factory Helpdesk

Traffic log data from HAProxy. It contains all data since 2019-10-01.

Security Groups:

  • Derisked - SEC-SNOWFLAKE-DATA-HAPROXY-DERISKED
    • Most of the columns are available in this category
  • Personal - SEC-SNOWFLAKE-DATA-HAPROXY-PERSONAL
    • This contains IP Addresses and Account ID
  • All - SEC-SNOWFLAKE-DATA-HAPROXY-ALL
    • This contains all columns and tables

StackOverflow.com

Type Update Frequency Ingestion Pattern Approver
1st Party (NY-RPTSQL01.StackOverflow) Daily Azure Data Factory Helpdesk

StackOverflow public Q&A data. It contains all data from all time.

Security Groups:

  • Derisked - SEC-SNOWFLAKE-DATA-STACKOVERFLOW-DERISKED
    • Most of the columns are available in this category
  • Personal - SEC-SNOWFLAKE-DATA-STACKOVERFLOW-PERSONAL
    • This contains email addresses and IP Addresses
  • All - SEC-SNOWFLAKE-DATA-STACKOVERFLOW-ALL
    • This contains all columns and tables

Qualtrics

Type Update Frequency Ingestion Pattern Approver

  • Site Satisfaction Survey - SEC-SNOWFLAKE-DATA-QUALTRICS-SITE-SATISFACTION-SURVEY
    • All data imported from the Site Satisfaction Survey

Salesforce

Type Update Frequency Ingestion Pattern Approver

Salesforce data

  • All - SEC-SNOWFLAKE-DATA-SALESFORCE-ALL

Requested Future Data Sources

Source Type Ingestion Pattern Status Documentation
Amplitude 3rd Party (Link) Fivetran Requested Link
BambooHR 3rd Party (Link) Fivetran Requested Link
Chargify 3rd Party (Link) Fivetran Requested Link
Clari 3rd Party (Link) Fivetran Requested Link
Google Analytics (via BigQuery) 3rd Party (Link) Azure Data Factory Requested Link
Greenhouse 3rd Party (Link) Fivetran Requested Link
PRIZM 1st Party NY-RPTSQL01.PRIZM Azure Data Factory Requested Link
Sage IntAcct 3rd Party (Link) Fivetran Requested Link
Sites (PubPlat) 1st Party NY-RPTSQL01.Sites Azure Data Factory Requested Link
Slack 3rd Party (Link) Fivetran Requested Link
Zuora 3rd Party (Link) Fivetran Approved Link

Data Ingestion Patterns

Azure Data Factory (ADF)

We use Azure Data Factory to ingest data from our on premise data center. This allows us to bulk copy data from our SQL Server instances into our Azure Data Lake where it is then loaded by Databricks into the rest of our data pipeline.

We control which tables are ingested via an Azure SQL Server (config-metadata.dbo.ObjectSchedulingData) to enable/disable the tables for ingestion as well as configure if they are full/delta loads, the frequency of the loads (triggers), and what query is run against the on premise SQL Servers to load the data.

ADF has multiple other connectors, so we may use it in the future for importing things like Google Big Query.

Fivetran

Fivetran is a Data Ingestion as a Service company. They specialize in making it easy to import data from a long list of 3rd party services through their extensive list of connectors.

We manage the data that we do (and don't) import through a GitHub repo and use GitHub actions to manage the state.

Databricks Notebook

Sometimes when there is no Azure Data Factory or Fivetran method to import data, we have to write our own custom script to import data. We are using Databricks Python notebooks to write the custom code necessary to download data from 3rd party data sources that don't have a better method for ingestion.

articles.title: EBR Certification
articles.body:
As part of being a Teams CSM, you'll be expected to deliver Executive Business Reviews (EBRs). In order to build the skills you'll need to deliver a successful EBR without the pressure of a live customer engagement, we've built this EBR certification.

First, read the following resources:

  • CSM EBR Process (Teams)

  • Knowledge Reuse 2.0 FAQ - Review the content as well as the training recording. Knowledge reuse is a key metric for the EBR; as of June 2023 we've migrated to what's being referred to internally as Knowledge Reuse 2.0.

  • How can I pull Knowledge Reuse for a customer?

  • Amplitude Review - You'll use Amplitude to pull the data you need to populate the EBR deck.

Then, you'll build an EBR deck for an existing customer, and present it internally in a mock EBR presentation. Work with your manager to select an appropriate customer to build the EBR deck for. Then, use the template below (make your own copy) in order to build a deck:

  • Template deck - Make a copy, and remove Datadog info in favor of your own customer's.

Presenting

Once you've created the presentation, let your manager know and schedule a 1-hour meeting with the following teammates:

  • Yourself

  • Your manager

  • Your peer mentor (optional)

  • Emily Chapman (Sales Enablement, optional)

Aim to present for between 30-45 minutes. The remaining time will be used for discussion and feedback. Be sure to focus on building a narrative around value with your presentation—this isn't a readout of graphs, but a space continue to justify spend on Stack Overflow for Teams through the lens of how the tool helps the customer accomplish their own goals.

articles.title: Collectives™ Admin/RM Private Discussions
articles.body:
WIP

What are Admin/RM Private Discussions?

Admin/RM "Discussions" is a private space for Collective administrators and recognized members to collaborate on managing and growing a Collective. Content in this space is private and not accessible by general Stack Overflow users or Collective members.

Participating users cannot gain reputation from participating in private discussions.

Who It’s For:

The feature has been enabled in both vendor and topic collectives for the following user roles:

  • Collectives Admins

  • Collectives Recognized Members

Moderation

This private space can be moderated by site moderators, our community team and to a smaller extent Collective admins.

It is not integrated with the Moderator Dashboard and Q&A moderation tooling.

Permissions

General

Permission Mods Admin Recognized Member Logged in & Anon users
View all X X X
View all - Deleted X X X - Only if author
Create X X X
Edit X - All posts X - All posts X - Only if author
Delete X - All posts X - All posts X - Only if author
View all revisions and timeline X X X
View all revisions and timeline - Deleted X X X - Only if author
Flag post X X X

Commenting

Permission Mods Admin Recognized Member Logged in & Anon users
Comment X X X
Upvote Comment - Requires 15-rep X X X
Edit Comment - Must edit within 5-minute grace period X - Can edit indefinitely, all comments X X
Delete Comment - Requires Commenting Privilege to delete comment on another user's post, no privilege required to delete comment on own post X - All comments X X
View comment timeline X
Flag comment X X X

Technical Specs

Persistence​

In the codebase and database, Collective Discussions are known as CollectiveDiscussions. CollectiveDiscussions are a type of Post (PostTypeId=16).

CollectiveDiscussions have additional characteristics not relevant to other post types, therefore an additional table called CollectiveDiscussions contains additional columns specific to this post type such as CollectiveId.

Replies to discussions are implemented with the same comments used in Q&A and are stored in the PostComments data table.

The PostHistory table is used to keep track of changes to a discussion post.

Post Features Configured for Collective Discussions

  • History - Used to enable the revision and timeline views
  • Commenting - Used to implement user replies

Privacy Considerations

Since discussion content is private, we have added checks to prevent content from being leaked into various parts of the SE network including:

  • Sites database and user's SE network profiles (SE Network Aggregrator)
  • API v2
  • Public SEDE
  • Quarterly Data Dumps

articles.title: DSR and You - How you can help keep our world DSR compliant!
articles.body:
DSR Compliance

Context

Personal Data

Personal data (a.k.a. Personally Identifiable Information or PII, protected data, etc.) can vary from region to region depending on which data protection law or regulation applies. Generally speaking, personal data means any personal information relating to, directly or indirectly, an identified or identifiable natural person, or household. This concept is crucial in the context of data protection and privacy regulations across the globe, as it helps define the scope of data subject rights (DSR).

Data subject rights are the rights of individuals to control their personal information, as recognized by various data protection laws such as the GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation) in the European Union, the CCPA/CPRA (California Consumer Privacy Act/California Privacy Rights Act) in the United States, and many others.

Examples

Directly identifying personal data refers to information that can be used to identify an individual without the need for additional data. Examples include:

  1. Full name
  2. Social Security number
  3. Passport number
  4. Driver's license number
  5. Email address
  6. Phone number
  7. Mailing address

Indirectly identifying personal data refers to information that, on its own, may not be sufficient to identify an individual but can be combined with other data to do so. Examples include:

  1. Date of birth
  2. Gender
  3. Job title
  4. Geolocation data
  5. IP address
  6. Browser cookies
  7. Device identifiers

How can we make decisions about adding Personal Data into our Systems?

The first thing we should always try to do is employ privacy by design principles, such as data minimization - i.e., find a way not to add more personal data into our system or replicate existing personal data in additional data storage locations/tools unless it is absolutely necessary.

Please ask yourself:

  1. Do we really need this piece of personal data?
  2. Can the personal data not already be found somewhere else in the schema?
  3. Do you have a sufficient legal basis for processing this personal data? In other words, can you make a legal justification to have this data, such as do we have valid consent or a contractual/legal obligation or a legitimate interest? (when in doubt, reach out to the legal privacy team)

If you've said yes to all of the above, then it is imperative that developers read the technical information in this article to make sure the dsr-cli can handle this new addition.

How do we handle DSR requests?

The current tooling is utilized by the Legal Privacy Team to execute data subject rights requests (e.g., access or erasure requests) in a manner that allows for auditability to ensure compliance with various global data and privacy protection regulations and laws. To do this, we have developed a CLI (Command Line Interface) that requires some manual interaction. This will allow the Legal Privacy Team to have more visibility into the personal data or PII of our users that we process. This additionally provides the Legal Privacy Team to perform and redactions and apply legal exceptions (which the previous implementation did not allow), as well as allow for more auditability of the data before and after an erasure is processed, for example.

Engineering Focused Details

dsr-cli

The dsr-cli is the tool created by #team-core-engineering to achieve the outcomes desired for this process. This CLI tool runs on an internal data-center computer (ny-chrdp01) where only legal can access.

At the high level, the cli executes against a few API endpoints for integrated third party systems as well as directly against our public platform databases. The Database implementation for finding data was implemented by our DBRE team including Aaron Bertrand and Terry Long. The third party integrations were implemented by Core-Engineering: Jacob Adams and Daniel McKinnon with consultation across the system owners.

Systems Currently in Scope

Systems where the tool currently executes against as a direct database action:

  1. All Public Platform Sites
  2. PRIZM Database
  3. Providence
  4. Area51
  5. StackExchange
  6. StackMail

Systems where the tool currently executes against an API endpoint:

  1. Marketo
  2. OpenIDProvider

How can dsr-cli handle new personal data our teams needs to add?

DB Stored Procedure Update

Some systems are already being mitigated through stored procedures that DBRE have implement across our systems. If adding personal data into one of those current scopes (mentioned above) it could be possible to modify the stored procedure to work with the new additions.

However, if this data is brand new, and part of new tables, it is beneficial to chose the API Endpoint option as this allows the team owning the schema/code to control how exports/erasures happen. At some point in the future, the golden path would include endpoints for all PII sources and disconnect the stored procedures. This is currently unplanned work.

API Endpoint (early stages)

We are currently iterating on this process and welcome suggestions and comments to #team-core-engineering so we can make this process more seamless.

We are asking teams that handle a certain domain of the business to handle the personal data export and erasure process themselves through an implemented API Endpoint. While we do not want to give guidance on what these API Endpoints should be named, there is guidance as to what they should return.

Two major compliance actions occur:

export - The endpoint that handles data access requests. This should accept an email as a post-parameter and return data in format shown in the dsr-cli's README of its repository.

erase - The endpoint that handles data erasure requests. This should accept an email as a post-parameter and return true or false signaling proper deletion or not.

Once you have these endpoints, please notify #team-core-engineering as soon as you can and we will add the domain's endpoints as another source of PII data to execute against.

Future Work (or What does a perfect world look like?)

We've not planned any current work to be done on this system. But a future does exist in combination with our Self Service initiative where we can formalize the process of where we can execute requests within all of our systems. We are also looking to integrate more with OneTrust in hopes that we can provide legal the same inspection of data and auditing they need while removing the manual nature of the CLI.

articles.title: 2023 Developer Survey results
articles.body:
Release date - June 13, 2023

Results site

Results Blog post

AI Blog post

Video recap of the highlights

AI deep dive analysis on Stack Overflow Labs

Press release

Sales assets

We’ve written copy for you to send to clients and prospects

  • Advertising

  • Employer Branding

  • Stack Overflow for Teams

We also have some slides of the highlights for you to use in your presentations.

We aren’t doing standalone presentations this year. If a client/prospect wants to learn more about the results or if they have questions, reach out to Erin Yepis and Joy Liuzzo.

Interesting data points

  • Stack Overflow continues to be a must-visit resource with 92.5% of respondents visiting regularly.

  • 77% of respondents feel favorable towards using AI tools as part of their development workflow - but we do see some differences between groups. 33% of respondents said increasing productivity is the most important benefit of using AI tools as part of a development workflow, however, only 42% trust the accuracy of the output of AI tools used in their development workflow.

  • For professional developers, they see the biggest benefit of using AI tools as part of their workflow as increasing productivity (37.4%), with secondary benefits of greater efficiency (27.9%) and speeding up learning (27.4%). For developers learning to code, they see the biggest benefits of using AI tools as part of their workflow as speeding up learning (42.4%) and increasing productivity (41.5%), with a secondary benefit of greater efficiency (33.7%).

  • 63% of all respondents spend more than 30 minutes a day searching for answers or solutions to problems.

    • People managers are more likely to spend time searching than individual contributors (42% vs. 36% spend 30 minutes or less).

  • Similar to last year, 66% of Professional Developers have at least some influence over their organization’s purchase of new technologies.

    • 99% of senior-level positions have some or a great deal of influence purchasing new technologies, followed by 86% of engineering managers.

  • For the first time in 13 years, we have data on how developers feel about Markdown files.

General talking points about the survey

  • ~90,000 developers from 185 countries took the survey between May 8, 2023 to May 19, 2023.

  • To identify which technologies to include in the survey this year, we included those used the previous year and added popular ones written in as “Other”. We submitted this list to our Meta community to solicit feedback and finalize the collection of technologies.

For data questions - Erin Yepis

For press questions - Matt Trocchio (send to press@stackoverflow.com)

For sales or marketing questions - Joy Liuzzo

articles.title: Data Platform Priorities and Async Collab - Week of 2023-06-12
articles.body:
Team Roster This Week​

Because it's hard to remember who was working on what at a given time 😂

Any holidays? Who's in?

  • Chelsea Zhang [cz] - Senior Data Engineer

  • Keith van der Meulen [kvm] - Data Engineer

  • Chris Belay [cb] - Senior Site Reliability Engineer

Note: Next Monday, June 19th is a US company holiday for Juneteenth.

Who's out?

  • Jason Lachniet [jl] - BI Engineer and Advocate - Parental leave 🐣

  • Kendra Little's last day is Weds, Jun 14 -- my access will get turned off in early afternoon Eastern

Who's on SAIL full time?

  • Constantine Kokkinos [CK] - Staff Data Engineer

  • Mitch Hamann [MH] - Senior Data Engineer

  • Jessica Clark [JC] - Senior Data Scientist

  • David Gibson [DG] - Senior Data Scientist

  • Michael Foree [MF] - Director of Data Platform and Data Science (flexing time for Data Platform leadership as well as SAIL)

This Week's Priority List​

Data Platform team members who are not on SAIL full time often flex to support SAIL work, which is reflected in these priorities.

  • [who?] what

  • [CZ] [cb] Facilitating EdTech resource decommission and validating we still have access to the data we intend to keep afterwards.

  • [CZ] Help answering questions around event hub use cases and improving the event hub bicep repo in below possible directions (or let me know if there are other things that are worth to address. Suggestions/advices will be super helpful.):

    • Adding validation workflow so that merge to main is not allowed if the template is not deployable.

    • Adding approver for PR.

    • Provide some guideline so that this repo can be used by many projects which wants to deploy event hub resources.

  • [KL] Finishing up last bits and bobs.

  • [CB] pouting about [KL]'s last day

  • [CB] Databricks deployed with Unity Catalog

On the side burner​

Things we don't have time to prioritize this week, but are helpful to track as we need to get to them at some point

  • Security improvements for Databricks -> Snowflake query. (Chris B has an ADR for this)

  • Cost reporting and analytics

  • GitHub branching strategy improvements to account for Databricks notebooks that read directly from the main branch

  • Data retention strategy - need to verify/set retention periods with infosec team and implement

Highlights from Last Week​

Option to share something cool from last week with others, as well as Future You

  • [who] what

  • [MF] Mitch refactored data pipelines to optimize usage and reduce cost. Initial estimates are that costs may drop as much as 80% for Databricks jobs.

Mitch described the refactoring work for the trafficlogs pipeline and StackOverflow pipeline:

  1. z-order the tables ( basically indexing and consolidating files in the delta lake ). It looks back 14 days on and optimizes the files, since the pipeline is never really going to look back more than 2 weeks for a load this is a big part of the improvements.

  2. Rewrite the query used to help track what was loaded to snowflake ( generic optimization for SQL ), and take advantage of the z-ordering.

  3. Tune the cluster sizes so that resources are properly allocated.

  4. Add lookback days for the range of data to look at ( today - 1day ), on incremental runs this is generally the only thing needed since it loads hourly.

What this did was reduce the number of clusters, and the total size of compute for them, to a much smaller amount and reduce the wait time for the compute. less compute + run time = less cost and faster pipeline.The SO Public one was refactored in a similar way, but also removes the need for dbt. Since it only refreshes once per day, it means that the total cost was also reduced.

Why is this an SO article?​

  • Increase transparency to stakeholders and users

  • Track team challenges and wins

  • Dogfood new ways to use Teams as a product

  • Align with future Async MBRs

articles.title: Teams is now on Azure cloud: here are the benefits
articles.body:
Background: Project Blueshift moved Stack Overflow for Teams from Stack’s data centers to the Azure cloud over five phases beginning in November 2022 and ending in June 2023. Hosted SOE was already in Azure. For more on the specific phases of Blueshift and the customer experience, see this article.

The completion of Blueshift Phase 4 marks a major milestone in our journey towards enhanced data security and scalability for Stack Overflow for Teams and sets the stage for a new era of scalability, reliability, and performance. We’re targeted to complete the fifth and final phase of Blueshift, “Cutting the Cord,” at the end of June 2023. The market launch for our cloud migration and resulting SOC2 compliance will be July 5, 2023.

In this article, we’ll cover the key benefits of migrating Teams from our datacenters to the cloud to further your understanding and help you communicate the value to our customers.

Azure Cloud Key Benefits

The migration to the Azure cloud brings many advantages that will positively impact our operations, efficiency, and overall business resilience. In addition to developing Teams features faster, here are four key benefits we can expect:

  • Enhanced Data Security

  • Scalability and Flexibility

  • Business Continuity

  • Cost Optimization

Enhanced Data Security

Azure provides robust security measures and compliance certifications, ensuring the safety and protection of our valuable data and setting Teams up for SOC 2 compliance. With Azure's advanced security features, we can confidently guard against potential threats, reduce the risk of data breaches, and ensure compliance with regulatory requirements.

SOC2 Compliance

Note: the market launch for SOC2 is July 5, 2023. We will provide assets and enablement materials to field teams. Please hold all public comms until then.

Developed by the American Institute of CPAs (AICPA), SOC 2 defines criteria for managing customer data based on five trust service principles: security, availability, processing integrity, confidentiality and privacy. Our SOC2 Type II report attests that the controls we put in place match these established and trusted requirements.

Security has always been a top priority for Stack Overflow, and compliance with SOC2 Type II provides an extra layer of validation and third-party assurance that our systems and networks are secure to the many technologists and knowledge workers who use Stack Overflow for Teams to share proprietary data within their organizations. Moving Teams to Azure allows us to meet certain infrastructure and compliance requirements for SOC 2 that would have been more difficult to achieve in our own datacenters.

Encryption in Transit and at Rest

Encryption in transit is a way to protect data as it’s transmitted across networks.  Stack Overflow requires the use of HTTPS for clients to communicate with the site to ensure encryption in transit for Teams customers. But for many organizations, encryption in transit is not enough to meet data privacy and compliance standards. Those customers are looking for the additional assurance of encryption at rest. Until now, encryption at rest has been available only to Enterprise customers.

Moving to Azure allows us to encrypt data at rest for the Business tier as well as Enterprise. We use SQL Transparent Date Encryption (TDE) to encrypt data at rest. Data in transit is encrypted using TLS 1.2 using a SHA256 certificate with a 2048-bit key.

Scalability and Flexibility

Azure's cloud infrastructure allows us to scale our resources quickly and efficiently. As our business grows, we can quickly adapt to increased traffic demands, ensuring a smooth user experience without compromising performance. This flexibility gives us the agility to meet our customers' evolving needs.

Business Continuity

We have significantly bolstered our disaster recovery capabilities by setting up Teams as a read-only secondary backup on Azure. In the event of any unexpected disruptions or system failures, we can seamlessly switch to the secondary backup and minimize downtime, thus ensuring uninterrupted service to our users. Additionally, Azure’s service-level agreement ensures 99.5% availability.  Please note that this is not a “disaster recovery (DR)” service, and is not equivalent to the SOE “Multi-region HA Upgrade” SKU.

Upon completion of Blueshift, the standard deployment of Teams will be a hosted SaaS, multi-tenant instance in Microsoft Azure. Stack Overflow manages the infrastratucture and platform that hosts the application.

High Availability

The Stack Overflow for Teams Business deployment is High Availability (HA) within a single region, meaning we offer two web servers located in a single region. HA ensures the application is functional even when part of the application is faulted. This includes the following scenarios:

  • Planned maintenance (server upgrades, patching, etc)

  • Unexpected errors (a server crashes)

  • Datacenter goes offline due to an extended outage

While there is no secondary instance running with HA, we are still replicating the customer’s data to a secondary region. If there is an outage in the Azure region, we would be able to rebuild a customer’s instance with a “best effort” recovery time objective. Note that SOE customers have the option to purchase an “Multi-region HA Upgrade.”

Teams Business instances will be hosted in the Azure- East Region (West Region for failover). Business customers do not have the option to choose their region.

Cost Optimization

Azure's pay-as-you-go model enables us to optimize our costs by only paying for the resources we use. This scalability, combined with efficient resource allocation and management, allows us to control our expenses and allocate our budget more effectively, ultimately driving our bottom line. This supports our company’s FY2024 strategic priority of Efficient & Predictable Revenue Growth.

articles.title: Dashworks Competitive Battlecard
articles.body:
Category: Enterprise Search

dashworks.ai

Positioning:

From their website: Your company’s all-in-one AI search assistant. Find any document, message, or email. Automate repetitive questions. Accelerate your team's productivity. All in a single secure platform.

Dashworks acts as a hub that combs your organization’s systems to find information. It’s a young company with few employees. They recently hired for their first marketing position, (March 2023), so while they are not a large threat right now, we’ll need to keep our eye on them going forward.

Where we win:

  • Focus on developer-focused platform with millions of users worldwide. This means a higher rate of adoption and usage resulting in a larger return on investment over time.

  • Focus on Stack Overflow for Teams as a standalone product. Teams has numerous integrations that enhance our product, but are not necessary to surface knowledge, as the platform itself is the knowledgebase. Dashworks’ integrations are necessary to ensure knowledge is surfaced, as it does not serve as a knowledgebase on its own.

  • Focus on our Q&A style of knowledge sharing for more organic and fresher content that is updated by the collective group.

  • Content Health programmatically identifies content that needs review, keeping knowledge relevant and fresh with less effort.

Core target:

  • Org-wide (sales, dev, marketing, it, support, research) solution

  • Special focus on onboarding new hires

Market Share/Key Customers:

  • TikTok, Front, Swiggy, Endeavor

  • Fairly new company (2022) with a limited amount of customers. No listing on G2.

Their Benefits:

  • Over 40 integrations available

  • Soc II Type 2 & GDPR compliant

  • Offers on-prem hosting

  • Set-up is fast - you can be up and running in just a few days.

  • UI is very similar to Slack, so it’s familiar to most customers and easy to use.

  • Offers a customizable homepage

Integrations:

  • GSuite

  • Github

  • Jira

  • Outlook

  • Asana

  • Confluence

  • Slack

  • Microsoft Teams

  • Salesforce

  • Full list of 40+ integrations

Their Weaknesses:

  • Dashworks has no listing on G2, so it is difficult to find reviews from customers.

  • It’s not a source of knowledge in and of itself - it relies on pulling information from external wikis, documents, etc. If the external documents go away, the knowledge is lost.

  • Focus is on finding existing knowledge, not creating new knowledge or expanding existing knowledge.

  • There is the risk of relevancy/accuracy - although it sorts for recency, there is no way for Dashworks to tell if the information it’s pulling is up to date.

Company Info:

  • Headquarters: San Francisco, CA

  • Founded: 2022

  • Employee size: 11 - 50 (16 employees on Linkedin)

  • Est. revenue: <$5M

Pricing:

Pricing is based on use - you only pay for active members. If a member becomes inactive, you automatically receive a credit.

30-day free trial, with the ability to cancel at any time. See all pricing details here.

Plan Price Details
Team $4.99/active user/month
Enterprise $9.99/active user/month Offers custom integrations, custom usage analytics, a dedicated success manager, and a dedicated implementation engineer

External Links:

  • Company Website: dashworks.ai

  • TechCrunch article on Dashworks

articles.title: (INTERNAL WIP) May 2023: Teams Release vNext Outlook
articles.body:
After 2+ years of successful releases on the Pod structure, Stack Overflow for Teams reached another milestone with 2023.1 (as of GA) as the first Enterprise release with a full Teams Pod line-up (Content, Discovery, Scale and newest Community Growth) including almost all new PM team + new Devs/Designers.

Fiscal Year 2024 (starting April 2023) sees a pivot point full-steam ahead towards a more agile Teams Release strategy to deliver value to customers faster/more frequently (FY24 company and PDEC goals along with SAIL project and restructuring). Below is an internal summary of Product Release goals and top areas to tackle as of May/Jun 2023 - stay tuned as we work to revamp the process while continuing to deliver impactful releases.

Product Release Goals

  • immediate: roll out Intercom to Enterprise ASAP

  • medium-term: simplify processes and shorten lead times for next releases

    • (especially given May events and other priorities/bandwidth considerations)

  • long-term/blue sky: continuous Enterprise releases - how can we ship “anytime”?

    • first need capability (app/infra, process and tooling) including Enterprise CI/CD

    • multi-dimension: Customer instance vs Environment vs Version vs. Feature (Flag) vs time

High-Level Approach

  • Simplify, Prioritize, Automate

    • Revisit operating assumptions to reduce overhead and streamline workflows - identify minimal compliance requirements as a baseline and add things back in as needed (such as customer experience considerations) - Release Notes, UAT, Beta, InfoSec Review, etc. with Legal and InfoSec discovery

    • Prioritize biggest gaps like Jira workflows and deployment e.g. Hebrides v3 while iterating to identify next bottlenecks

    • Automate wherever possible

  • Continuous Everything: Planning, Build, Testing, Documentation, Release Notes, Marketing Messaging, field enablement / support training, InfoSec Review, etc.

    • Shift from chasing release dates getting work ready to ship to having a backlog of DONE work ready to ship

    • Reduce/shorten Done -> Ready to Release, from afterthought to part of the process and reduce current ~2.5month from planning to delivery

    • Decouple deployment from release with Feature Flags for change control in phased rollouts

Game Changers

  • Recent internal On-premises announcement and this new branching/versioning scheme proposal could not have come at a better time and opens implementation options

Feel free to reach out with any questions and ideas!

articles.title: Container APM: Traducir Case
articles.body:
As part of Traducir migration, we decided to deploy Traducir as a containerised application. We went with App Services as the container platform instead of Container Apps. This decision was based on our experience with App Services and existing tooling we have in place.

Currently, we are able to get some basic telemetry data and logs thanks to the integration with Azure and Datadog. However, we cannot get full APM experience as our other App Services based applications have because of lacking support for containerised App Services APM.

We have evaluated the options to enable APM and decided to leave it as is since we have enough observability with the logs and a basic availability dashboard and Traducir has extremely low load (180 requests per hour).

Option 1: App Services Multi-container Deployment

Multi-container deployment is currently in preview and none of our CD tools (GHA and Octopus Deploy) support it. The only option to do the deployment is using az cli with a docker-compose file: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/app-service/tutorial-multi-container-app. If we had to do it, we could've done it for GHA. This also arises a question about deployments: "Do we want GHA to be our only CI/CD tool?". We don't think it is the right time to answer this question even GHA provides great deal of workflow management such as deployment review process.

Additionally, it does not end just with the deployment. The example in Tracing Docker Applications needs to be converted to docker-compose and tested to ensure it works. We weren't sure whether we should invest our time and we don't think containerised App Services is the path we'd like to pave.

Option 2: Install Datadog Agent to container image

We don't think we should ever promote installing a third-party agent to any of our application's container image. There are a few reasons why we don't want to do it:

  • Lost isolation
  • Increased attack surface
  • Dependabot fatigue
  • Larger image size
  • Possible inability to run locally

Option 3: Switch to Container Apps

Do not confuse Container Apps with Container Instances. Here's the comparison: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/container-apps/compare-options

This one is closer to the road we'd like to pave but GHA is the only CD tool can be used. It runs workloads on AKS without providing direct access to Kubernetes APIs. It is an offering somewhere between Container Instances and AKS.

The major advantage of using Container Apps is the ability to provide Kubernetes Pod resource-like YAML configuration and possibility to run sidecar containers. As seen on this example, multiple containers can be defined for a deployment as if you would do in traditional Kubernetes deployment. However, Datadog's documentation recommends installing the agent in application container's image. That was the major reason why we ruled out Container Apps for now.

Option 4: Falling back to Vanilla App Services

It's really not an option while we consider containerisation for all the services and providing a shared deployment/instrumentation on local/dev/prod. It will definitely enable the APM and it is a well-paved road but it's not the road we want to fallback.

articles.title: Generate data for test environments
articles.body:
A problem that people frequently run into is that when there is a need to test a feature that uses more than one Q/A combo it becomes super tedious to set that up and you end up spending loads of time just massaging the test data into place.

The Test Data Generator allows you to create test data in a predictable way while still adding some randomness into the mix.

How does it work?

The Test Data Generator allows you to specify the rough shape of the test data you need and it will generate a set of JSON files that contains the full set of users, questions, answers, tags, departments.. basically everything needed to pretend you have an environment that was built up by users.

These JSON files are consumed by the import command of the StackOverflow.Setup which will import that data into the environment of choice.

Current features

The application generates:

  • Users + accounts
  • Questions
  • Answers
  • Tags
  • Departments
  • Job titles
  • OrgMemberDetails (links a user to a department and/or job title)
  • Connections

You can control the volume and shape of the test data by setting these options

  • Total number of users to create
  • The start date of the site (used for the CreationDate of all users)
  • The department / job title hierarchy
  • The distribution of users across departments (even or randomized)
  • The distribution of job titles in a department (even or randomized)
  • The ratio of users to questions. Basically: how many questions does each user ask. Can be even or randomized (with a min and max)
  • The question to answer ratio. Basically: how many answers does each question

Usage

The application uses a fluent approach which let's you quickly configure the generator:

var options = new TestDataGeneratorOptionsBuilder()
    .UsingRandomSeed(12)
    .OutputTo(@"c:\temp\generation-output")
    .WithSiteStartDate(new DateTime(2023, 3, 1))
    .WithNUsers(150)
    .WithUserToQuestionRatio(Ratio.Randomized, 0, 12)
    .WithQuestionToAnswerRatio(QuestionToAnswerRatio.RandomizedLongTail, 1, 5)
    .WithTagsPerQuestion(0, 3)
    .Build();

A concrete example can be found in the Program class.

Extending the Test Data Generator

In case the Test Data Generator does not quite generate what you want it should be straightforward to modify it.

Most likely, that will mean changing one of the option builder methods or the relevant generation method

Adding a new data category

For situations where the generator currently does not generate the type of data you need, you will need to add it in two places:

  • The Test Data Generator (create the relevant option and generation methods)
  • StackOverflow.Setup

Adding a new data category to StackOverflow.Setup

Note: This is a very bare-bones list, YMMV

Step 1: Add the import method to ImportAsync

Step 2: Add a id-mapping dictionary to SiteImportState

This is what helps map the id's in the JSON file for your category to the imported entities. Use this collection (and the other ones!) when you have references in your generated test data. For example, use QuestionIdsOldToNew to get the inserted id of a question from your data set by it's logical id in the data set.

Step 3: Add the data file to SiteImportData

This is what reads the new JSON file from the zip file that is used by StackOverflow.Setup. Depending on your need you may want to add a check that the data category is included in the zip file.

Step 4: Add the import method

Create a new partial class and implement the actual importing logic. SiteImportHelper.Connectivity has been added most recently and should give a good example of how to write one.

Step 5: Test.

Run StackOverflow.Setup with the import command against a local environment. See here for details.

An example of the import command:

$NETWORK = "Blueshift"
$ENVIRONMENT = "Local"
$IMPORT_ZIP = "C:\path\to\dataset.zip"

.\StackOverflow.Setup.exe data import `
-sitesConnection "Data Source=sql;Initial Catalog=${ENVIRONMENT}.Teams.Sites;User Id=sa;Password=Password1!" `
-channelsConnection "Data Source=sql;Initial Catalog=${ENVIRONMENT}.Teams.Channels;User Id=sa;Password=Password1!" `
-dataHost stackoverflowteams.local/c/test-team-1 `
-channelSlug test-team-1 `
-channelName "Test Team 1" `
-deploymentEnvironment "${ENVIRONMENT}.${NETWORK}.Channels" `
-importUserType $IMPORT_ZIP `
-threads 4 `
-skip $SKIP_IMPORTER_TESTDATA

Run this from your repository under \utils\StackOverflow.Setup\bin.

articles.title: Datadog alerts for route error rates in #team-pubplat-alerts
articles.body:
There are several monitors set up that are continuously monitoring the rate of success vs errors for each endpoint on the public platform. These have all been given the error_rate tag.

The goal for these is to give us a general indicator of whether something is broken, without having to maintain so many different monitors for every endpoint. They should not replace important user-focused metrics.

There are different monitors set up for different time spans:

  1. 5 minutes. This should quickly catch errors in highly-used routes like /questions/{id}.

  2. 1 hour. For those endpoints that aren't hit as often.

  3. 2 days. Designed to catch problems with things like the daily scheduled tasks.

Each of these monitors:

  • Filter to just product:pubplat, env:prod and service:stackoverflow. These alerts don't monitor the API, PR environments or Teams, for example.

  • Are multi-alerts by resource_name. We get a separate alert for each route that goes above the error rate threshold.

  • Use a cutoff for an absolute minimum count of errors within the timeframe. This prevents a small number of errors jumping the rate to above the threshold due to a small blip.

  • Notify the #team-pubplat-alerts Slack channel.

  • Reference this dashboard (filtered to the route that triggered the alert) to dig into the error rates.

  • Automatically resolve themselves when error rates drop back.

Iterating & Tweaking

We should be iteratively working towards having alerts that:

  1. Trigger when something is wrong. We need confidence that the site is functioning. We want to trust that, when we deploy a change, no alerts generally means we're good 👍

  2. Do not trigger when nothing is wrong. False-positives leads to alert fatigue. We become desensitised and end up ignoring the alerts. We could miss important alerts due to too much noise.

Working towards this 1:1 relationship will involve lots of learning and fine-tuning.

See this question: Alerts are firing that aren't real problems. How can I reduce noise?

articles.title: Connectivity in Teams - Functionality and architecture
articles.body:
In this article

Connectivity in Teams describes the reasoning why we built the Connectivity feature. This article describes the feature as it's been implemented and the underlying architecture.

Functionality

The Connectivity feature stores information on the department or job title of whoever answers a question to surface information about how departments or job titles are connected. In other words: Show which departments are answering questions from which department (and the same for job titles).

In order to track this information, the Connectivity feature relies on the department and job title of a user which is ingested through SAML login flow.

Terminology

Connection

The link between a question and an answer. It captures:

  • Department of the question owner
  • Job Title of the question owner
  • Department of the answer owner
  • Job Title of the answer owner

Self-connection

A connection where the question owner and the answer owner are the same

Source

Either a department or a job title. Used in the context of filtering connections

articles.title: Database Backup Download Instructions for SOE Clients
articles.body:
This is a How-To Guide that can be shared with clients should they have additional questions on how to download their database backups, starting from accessing SendSafely which is how Support sends the SAS URL.

1. Go to the secure file transfer service URL : https://transfer.secretoverflow.com/xxxxxx

2. Enter your email address in the field and click "Submit"

3. You will be sent an email with a verification code. (If you don't see this email in a few minutes, check your spam/junk folder)

4. Enter the verification code from your email into the field on the secure file transfer website and tick the checkbox to agree to the terms of service. Then click "Submit".

5. You will then see the file that contains your SAS URL. Download this file by clicking on it.

​

Open the file you downloaded, then follow the steps below to use Azure Storage Explorer to open the SAS URL. We'll go through each step in the process for you...

1. Open Azure Storage Explorer

2. Right mouse click on "Storage Accounts" and choose "Connect to Azure Storage"

3. Select "Blob Container"

4. Select "Shared access signature URL (SAS)"

​

5. Enter a Display name for your own purpose and the https:// URL to the storage account. (This is the "SAS URL" value from the file you downloaded from our secure file transfer service.)

​

6. Click the "Next" button for a Summary

7. Click the "Connect" button to connect. In the screenshot below, your container is connected and open and the bacpac file is shown on the right:

You can then use the Azure Storage Explorer like a normal Windows Explorer and download your bacpac file. (Right-click on the bacpac file and select "Download".)

articles.title: How To: Vivun Activity Tracking
articles.body:
Activity Types

The Sales Engineering team uses Vivun Calendar Sync to quickly enter activities spent pursuing revenue.

We have a short list of Activity Types to choose from:

Activity Type Description
Business Value Gathering inputs via discovery, preparing business case deck, presenting business case.
Demo Demo of the product. Include any Disco/Demo meetings.
Discovery A formal, separate discovery meeting.
InfoSec/Security Time spent on a security questionnaire, meeting with the client's InfoSec, or other security-related activity.
Post Sales Misc Catch all for various post-sale activities to include MBR, QBR, EBR, or another meeting with paying customer and there's not a clear upsell opportunity.
POV - Intro/Journey Presentation of the POV Introduction slides and/or describing the overall customer journey.
POV - Kickoff Presentation of the formal POV Kickoff slides.
POV - Wrap Up Presentation of the POV Wrap Up slides.
POV - Other Catch all for other POV-related meetings or activities. This includes trainings, Stackathons, weekly check-ins, hosted checklist, etc.
Preparation Prep time to get ready to deliver a deal-related deliverable or activity.
RFx (RFP/RFI/RFQ) Time spent toward a RFP/RFI/RFQ.
External Meeting Catch all to include any other client meetings.
Internal Meeting Catch all to include any other internal meetings related to customer work. Do not log forecast calls, Educasts, 1-1s, or other internally facing activities.

Attaching to POVs

If the activity is associated to a POV, remember to attach your Activity to the deliverable as well.

Clarification

  • Focus on activity that's revenue-driving and related to a specific deal.

  • Don't log your regular 1-1s with AEs, your manager, and so on.

  • Don't log miscellaneous internal meetings, e.g. educasts, all hands.

  • Use the most specific option available.

  • Use the appropriate activity type if you're joining a client call to support another SE or cover while someone is away/out.

  • If you're onboarding and shadowing another SE, please do not enter the activity

  • When in doubt, pick "POV-Other", "External Meeting" or "Internal Meeting".

Bugs

  • Don't use the "recurring meeting" functionality in Vivun until a bug gets fixed.

Related

  • How do I get started with Vivun as an SE?

  • Should (all) Internal Meetings be logged in Vivun, by SE's?

  • How should a supporting SE be added to an opportunity in Salesforce and/or Vivun?

  • How can I log a POV wrap up call in Vivun?

  • How can I save time and automate logging Vivun activities?
