articles.title: Teams rolls out upgraded Intercom implementation
articles.body:
What is Intercom?

Intercom is the tool we use to communicate with Teams administrators and end users. Until now, we’ve used it for emails and small pop-ups to alert customers to new features or actions they need to take and drive onboarding, adoption, and value realization for the product. Currently, Intercom is only available on Free, Basic, and Business tiers (it will be added to SOE this summer). Intercom is being reinstalled on Teams pages using javascript, deprecating our current iframe solution, which will enable a new set of tools to be used to engage Teams users.

This launch is very exciting for Teams, as it will empower a faster and more effective onboarding process for new users, and provide an engagement experience that is more immersive for existing users.

Launch timeline and plan availability​

Timeline​

SO Internal and internal demo sites, except SOE demos: Tuesday, May 30, 2023

GA release: Wednesday, May 31, 2023

No downtime or interruption for our customers is expected with this release.

**Availability for Stack Overflow for Teams plans:**​

Free  ✅

Basic  ✅

Business ✅

Enterprise ❌ (Release date TBD; late June-early July 2023)

What is changing?

With the javascript version of Intercom, we will be able to engage with customers in new ways that help them learn about the product and features.

For example, in product tooltips calling attention to specific on screen elements and product tours that guide users through the product motion will become available.

These changes will help us:

  • Onboard users faster

  • Highlight new features

  • Provide more opportunities for engagement within the product and minimize the number of emails we send (user happiness)

  • Increase monthly active users (MAUs) by improving product “stickiness”

How will the new tools affect the user experience?

Until now, Intercom has been installed using an iframe, which limits in-app engagement to posts and chatbots that can be presented in the iframe on the bottom-right corner of the page. You may have seen one appear on SO Internal. They look like this:


With the change to a javascript implementation, users will be presented with messaging that appears in the most directly relevant area on the page in the form of product tours, tooltips, and checklists that will guide users to perform key actions that will facilitate a faster time to value realization and habit formation.

For instance, a product tour will lead users to perform a series of actions on the page by highlighting page features.

Users can also receive a checklist, delivered in the messenger in the bottom corner of the screen, that will instruct users on actions to perform to complete their onboarding. This checklist will include a time estimate that will signal to users how quickly they can become adept at using Teams. (Note that the checklist will not conflict with the in-app checklist.) Here is an example of a checklist:

Tooltips will allow us to create visual cues for users in the product that highlight and elaborate on the value of specific product features, separate from product tours:

We will follow up with a more detailed explainer on how each of the new features work and the different levers we have available to pull when targeting different user segments.

Will users notice anything different on launch day?

No, no changes will be visible to customers at the time of launch. They will notice a change when the first Intercom experiment leveraging these new features is sent.

When will the first Intercom campaign be launched using the new features?

The first campaigns that will be launched will be new onboarding flows that are designed to get users familiar with the product, quickly realize its value, and incorporate Stack Overflow for Teams into users’ workflow much more quickly. These campaigns will go out to all new administrators and end-users on Free, Basic, and Business, and will leverage product tours (new feature), checklists (new feature), posts (existing feature), and emails (existing feature). These are planned for launch early in early-mid June 2023.

Intercom upgrade launch activities

  • Talking points for Customer Success Intercom Javascript - Notes for CS and Support

  • Internal Slack announcement

Because customers will not see a visible change, there are no planned customer comms with the initial launch, and no new pieces of collateral.

articles.title: Project Insert: Exploring how to leverage LLMs to solve the Empty restaurant syndrome
articles.body:
Internal use only - do not share

Project INSERT ("Ingesting kNowledge to Solve the Empty RestauranT syndrome")

  • Initial outline by @balpha in #creator-design-sprint
  • Figma prototype shared used for user research
  • StackEngLabs/project-insert on GitHub
  • Visualization using PR environments (index, example, GitHub with instructions)

This Article is a high-level overview of the direction the Content-pod is taking or thinking of taking to tackle the Empty Restaurant problem, which was identified as the most impactful proposal in the #creator-design-sprint. Please stop us if you see something that is already solved!

The goal is to de-risk and onboard content-pod devs into working with LLMs. A lot of the work revolves around using LangChain.

The point man for the dev effort is @balpha.

Things we're validating

This is focused on the developer perspective to de-risk ideas, starting with more low-effort ones. There are more assumptions and Hypothesis that Alec Smith and Phoebe Day are validating with customers. See the #creator-design-sprint channel: Slack thread about alignment.

  • LLMs are good at Summarization, therefore they will be able to reword documents into Q&A a format
  • LLMs are good at Keyword extraction, therefore they will be able to produce tags from documents
    • We can extract domain-specific keywords, like blueshift in addition to generic ones (engineering).
  • LLMs have wider context that they were trained on, therefore we can generate viable questions from only partial data
    • Which we then feed into a Search index to generate actual Question body / Question answers
  • We can extract structured data out of LLM responses

More info can be found in the GitHub repo README files & Jupiter notebooks.

Approach 1: Single file flow

How far can we get just rewording a single document?

Yellow parts are what we've been experimenting with. Blue ones are what we consider viable ideas. White is performed manually, we are NOT validating it (source).

Approach 2: Top down

Can we create questions separately from answers and leverage other SAIL teams to provide answers that are not limited to a single source document?

The diagram below shows our ownership assumptions. SAIL teams have invested a lot more time into this than Content-pod and some reading we've done relies on similar approaches:

  • creating an index based on which you select relevant context for generating Q&A)

  • writing various integrations - even if we own that bit this is low risk

What we do want to validate is:

  • what metadata can we obtain from integrations - e.g. can we get view counts from confluence

  • is using a subset of Documents enough to solve our problem - use metadata or manual user input to call the Single document flow

Non-Goals

  • Not validating that we can import into StackOverflow

  • Not using any Data Science / ML - we are evaluating LLMs

  • Scaling to all company documents - given enough time / money we are confident it would be possible. Some napkin math.

References for future work

  • PubPlat Grading Doc - Linked by Yaakov Ellis to show how questions are graded, slack thread

  • StackEngLabs/awarren-ai-search - Code for https://asksoteams.azurewebsites.net/ by Alex Warren & Discovery pod. Looks like this.

  • LangChain - Docs give a really nice overview of various approaches. We are using things like their map-reduce chain and also their automatic document splitting. A ton of references to research articles also.

  • Supabase docs search blogpost - there is an accompanying video from the creator walking through preprocessing files, splitting into chunks, generating embeddings & passing context to provide search results

  • LLM Terminology - SO internal article

articles.title: Data Platform Priorities and Async Collab: Week of 2023-05-29
articles.body:
Team roster this week​

Note: US Holiday on Monday, May 29

  • Chelsea Zhang, Senior Data Engineer

  • Keith van der Meulen, Data Engineer

  • Chris Belay, Senior SRE

  • Kendra Little, Technically a PM 🌴 OOO Tues & Weds, back Thursday

OOO all week

  • Jason Lachniet, Power BI strategist and Metrics Store whisperer: 🐣 Parental leave till June 19

This week's priority list

In addition to the work below, all team members will likely spend some time on at least one SAIL initiative. We are ramping up to help with:

  • SAIL Event Streaming

  • SAIL Data Model Testing/ Data Monetization

1: EdTech wind-down, de-comm (when Awareness team is ready)

  • Chris Belay will help with the Azure SQL Database/ terraform steps, which will happen after the Awareness team removes their dependencies. - https://stackoverflow.atlassian.net/browse/DAPL-575

2: Structured Pipeline implementation

  • Chelsea will be creating Jiras for covering tests and other TODOs in structured pipelines, then prioritizing and working through them.

3: Ingesting Data for Business Analytics

  • Keith will be working through connecting Zuora with Fivetran and documenting the end-to-end process from landing the data in the Data Lake in Delta Tables, to creating structured pipelines that land the data in Snowflake.

  • Kendra will be working through clarifying columns and datatypes returned from 1st party APIs for teams metadata, documenting the 1st party APIs and validating its correctness, and working more in the compliance process.

4: Databricks

  • Chris created a new repo for Databricks (https://github.com/StackEng/databricks) to help contain the docs and config relevant to it in one place. It's a large product with a lot of moving parts that should have its own home. This will result in a productionized environment suitable for the needs of Project SAIL.

5: Platform Observability

  • Chris will continue work on trying to connect things up to Datadog

On the side burner​

  • [kl] Cost reporting - Cost reporting and how we can reduce ongoing costs is an important initiative, but we are unlikely to make progress on it this week due to prioritization

  • [kl] Restart discussions on Functional and Performance cookies - Still important, but minimal time this week

  • [kl] Facilitate discussions regarding Amplitude data - Planning to follow up in the future due to the short week

Highlights from last week you'd like to share or capture?

  • [KL] Ryan Abella contributed metric store changes for MAUs and Chelsea helped walk me through PR review. Ryan hit report performance issues in Power BI and we fixed it by clarifying our stance on Direct Import (it's OK!), and the dashboard is now much snappier and using the new metrics. Most of this is due to Ryan Abella and Jason Lachniet's working together-- so awesome 🏆

  • [CZ] EdTech decommission:

      1. Workflows are deactivated and cleaned up on dev and prod environments.
      1. Logic that uses targeting cookie is finally merged in with explanation in repo wiki.
      1. Documentation has been added to repo wiki including the 'lesson learned' based on the tech retro last week and a list for the remaining EdTech data (location and access).

  • [CZ] Databricks PROD workflows that run on schedules are now sending out Slack notification to team-data-accelerators-alerts on failures. For configuring future workflows, we can simply hook them up with the existing slack notification destination.

  • [CB] I had a good time off that resulted in 76 new trees being planted!

  • [KV] There were 9 new data ingestion requests created last week, many for Fivetran enabled sources.

  • [KV] Wrote a new Data Team Data Sources article officially listing the data sources we ingest with a bunch of relevant information about each source

  • [KV] Started work on figuring out what data risks and issues we have for ingesting Sites and PRIZM so that we can start ingesting them soon.

Why is this an SO article?​

This is part of an experiment in using SO Internal articles for weekly async priorities sharing, recording of recent wins, and status updates for Data Platform team members who are not currently 100% dedicated to Project SAIL. Some of the work described here may support Project SAIL but is not being carried out wholly by a SAIL pod.

By publishing this regularly in SO, we hope to:

  • Increase transparency to stakeholders and users across Stack;

  • Track team challenges and wins, both for learning and to recognize our achievements;

  • Dogfood new ways to use Teams as a product;

  • Document team priorities and activities in a way that will align with future Async MBRs.

​

articles.title: Updated button styling for vote arrows across the Stack Exchange network sites
articles.body:
Ship date: May 30, 2023

Today, the CProd Consumers team graduated an experiment to update the button styling for vote arrows on Stack Overflow and across the network sites. The experiment was conducted about a year ago 

Who It’s For?

✅ All users on Stack Overflow question pages

✅ All users on Stack Exchange network site question pages

Why We Built It

In addition to having a consistent styling across products (Teams and Collectives), the updated styling makes the buttons more actionable which should lead to more engagement with them.

The results from the experiment were statistically significant with a net 28% increase in overall votes, but we shelved it for two reasons: 1) Meta brought up a few accessibility bugs that needed to be addressed and 2) at the time, we wanted to roll this into a broader (Site Modernization) initiative but it never took off. 

Additionally, the circumstances have changed with a recent drop in metrics across the board (fewer participants visiting and contributing), so we decided to move forward. The change will also support an upcoming change from the Community Enablement team to remove the barrier for upvoting which will welcome newer participants. Voting is one of the lowest barriers to participate, yet 1 in 4 new users who attempt to vote are unable to do so.

User Experience

Before After

Resources

  • Jira Epic (Experiment, Graduation)

  • Figma design

  • Experiment results

  • Meta announcement

articles.title: How-To: CSM Tagging Exercise with Clients
articles.body:
Tagging Recommendations for Clients

I thought I'd share some insights and how-tos for a recent adventure in helping clients manage their tags in order to increase searchability and decrease time to answer.

  1. Identify the main issue.

    1. It might be time to answer is slow, it might be that they have had SO4T for a while and have 1200 tags and not enough SMEs, or it might be that they have a bunch of unanswered questions.

    2. Figure out what is priority #1, #2, and #3 and frame that into your recommendations after this exercise.

  2. Ask for them to do a brief call with you or send via email in order for them to share a screenshot of each page of their tags.

    1. Under these tag names, you will be able to see, How many posts exist for each tag, How many have SMEs and how many do not, How many posts have been made this year or this month, and any description the tag has. From there, this will help you understand what they are working on, what developers are most interested in, and what the crux of the issue is.

    2. I have started with their top 5 pages of tags, so we work with the ones people are using the most first.

  3. This part is a lot of work, but it's worth it!

    1. Use it as your Power-Up for the week or two weeks if that helps!

    2. Make a Google Sheet like this.

    3. Enter every tag into it, with what matters, like the posts, if it has an SME and a synonym suggestion. I also did how many posts have been created this year and this month for this client.

  4. For assistance with synonyms, use your knowledge of the client, read the descriptions in the tags on the screenshots, and use the #plusone-testing channel for assistance.

  5. Host a call with your client to walk through this worksheet and recommend to them the next steps based on the results.

    1. For this client, it's clear that some tags are getting a lot of attention from users and have no one home to answer the questions. So assigning SMEs was a top priority.

    2. I was able to offer them two options: a) assign an SME and b) have this tag go into a synonym for now until you can so that someone will be able to answer.

  6. A recommendation, no matter what, is to empower moderators to suggest tags that are active if someone creates a new one with no SME or is using a lesser-known or not assigned tag.

    1. This will help with adoption since people are probably annoyed not getting answers to their questions.

    2. And this is a great way to resolve it quickly while doing a lot of your client's dirty work for them.

  7. Track the results via this Tag Usage Report. This way, you are providing a ton of value, recommendations and expertise and tracking the results to validate your work and value to the client in future MBRs and EBRs.

    1. Additional resources here.

    2. How are customers getting metrics for multiple tags today

    3. <https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1xLM9HUJRHPDD0N6J1mk_Pigsks_te2aDS3CHMGZTO4w/edit#gid=1212937863 >

    4. https://us-32401.app.gong.io/call?id=1387697420142789828

Have fun! Be creative! And I hope this helps make a client's pain a little easier and your ability to drive value even easier.

articles.title: SE Working Tools Best Practices
articles.body:
SEs at Stack Overflow use Slack, GSuite, and Zoom as a core part of their day-to-day workflows. This article outlines some common best practices for those tools for folks who have not used them before, or who would like a refresher.

Setting working hours

Stack is a distributed company, which means the person scheduling a meeting with you may not remember your local time zone. To make it very easy for them to do so and to allow for auto-scheduling of meetings, set working hours and the correct local timezone in Google Calendar:

  • Setting working hours

  • Setting primary timezone

GCal Suggest a Time

If you’re looking for open times for a meeting for you and a colleague, use Google’s suggested time feature.

In GCal, click Create > Event > More Options, and add the appropriate guests. Set the meeting to the right length of time, and then click “suggested times” underneath the guest list. You’ll see an easy list of all of the times that people are 1) free and 2) in working hours. Pick one, and you’re set. This is also great for generating a list of possible meeting times to send to a client, since you’ll know both you and your AE are free at that time.

GCal Slack Integration

GCal has a Slack integration that can message you your events for the day, update your Slack status to show you’re in an event, and can ping you right before your meetings start. Open the Google Calendar app in Slack (cmd/ctrl + k, search for “Google Calendar”), and from there you can configure your preferences.

Install Zoom GCal Add-on

SEs use Zoom for client meetings (and meetings, generally). Install the Zoom for Google Workspace add-on so that you can easily add Zoom info to all of your meetings. Use the dropdown arrow next to the “add Google Meet video conferencing” link and select the Zoom option; clicking the “make it a Zoom meeting” button below will not remove the Google Meet link, which gets confusing.

/Zoom Command

If you need to meet with a colleague quickly, type “/zoom” into Slack and press enter. A link will be automatically generated. You do not need to copy the link from Zoom!

Add all documents to Client folders

All documents related to a customer need to go into their Clients folder, not the “My Drive” default. “My Drive” is a local drive, and others cannot access it if you’re not available; Clients is in the shared drive, and so others can actually access the documents there.

Add GDrive Shortcuts

For any folders you regularly use in GDrive, add a bookmark to My Drive. Open the folder, click the arrow next to the folder name, and click “Add Shortcut to Drive”:

You can add a shortcut to this folder in “My Drive” so that you can easily click into the shared Clients (etc.) folder. No need to navigate the nested folder structure in GDrive!

Moving Docs in GDrive

If you do make a doc in your private drive that you need to move into the shared drive, use that same downward arrow menu, and click “Move to” in order to move the document to the shared drive. No need to copy and paste the doc contents!

Use Markdown in GDrive

GDrive supports markdown! Use these instructions to enable it if that’s how you prefer to format docs.

articles.title: Github Code Scanning PR Approval(s) Needed
articles.body:
As part of our Secure SDLC uplift, Infosec will be turning on code scanning for all repos in StackEng. This will involve us creating a new branch on the repo, adding a .yaml file in the GH Actions folder generated by the code scanning tool, opening a PR, then merging it with main. Once code scanning is turned on, you can go into any repo in StackEng and begin remediating the findings from code scanning under the Security tab > Code scanning.

FYI code scanning will not be blocking, you will still be able to merge even if new items are identified.

Action needed: The only action that may be needed from your end is if a repo has a merge blocker for PR approval, please approve and merge the PR if there are no failed tests. Some of the repos have autobuild issues and we'll be working with the teams directly to remediate them.

You may also receive emails or alerts about this activity, please feel free to reach out to me (@sliu or @infosec) directly with any questions about code scanning on GitHub or this process. Thank you!

articles.title: Data Platform Priorities and Async Collab: Week of 2023-05-05
articles.body:
Team roster this week

Because someday we will not recall who was working in SAIL at which time 😂

  • Chelsea Zhang, Senior Data Engineer, Bringer of Pipelines, Heir of Data Quality

  • Keith van der Meulen, Data Engineer, ADF wrangler and Fivetran Tamer

  • Kendra Little, Technically a PM

OOO this week...

  • Jason Lachniet, Power BI strategist and Metrics Store whisperer: 🐣 Parental leave till June 19

  • Chris Belay, Senior SRE of All That Data: 🌴 OOO this week (Canadian holiday and vacation)

This week's priority list

1: EdTech wind-down, preparing for de-comm

  • Business benefits of doing this: save money on infra, avoid processing users data when we have no reason for it, simplify environment by removing things we aren't using, tidy up data retained and code for future insights/projects.

  • Chelsea is handling the codebase, job workflows, and data side of this-- changes will go out this week: https://stackoverflow.atlassian.net/browse/DAPL-577

  • Chris Belay will help with the Azure SQL Database/ terraform steps, which will happen after the Awareness team removes their dependencies (which will be after Chris is back from holiday) - https://stackoverflow.atlassian.net/browse/DAPL-575

2: Supporting Community Metrics / user segmentation exploration

  • Keith - worked with a number of different analysts and teams to find common themes, common work, and common ideas

    • It is probably worth setting up a common group to work towards setting up the proper base metrics and to organize work so that there isn't duplication

    • Figuring out "value" metrics for users is challenging at best. Determining a number of different heuristics to apply to user segments could help show the value that different segments provide and then look for low value

3: Admin DataSync sources wrangling

  • Keith - Zuora data request form should hopefully be approved early this week and be ready for Fivetran setup this week. This will be used to help document a procedure for adding new sources.

  • Keith - Work is going into getting the PubPlat Sites DB ready/approved for ingestion into the data platform. PRIZM is also being explored to figure out what needs to be loaded into the data platform and what types of data and risks (Teams data) are included in PRIZM.

  • Kendra - Looking into the two 1st party API calls from AdminDataSync and doing other project work for Retiring Looker & Admin Data Sync by Adding Data Sources to the Data Platform

    • 1st party API notes

      • One API is from Providence, so we'll likely not want to introduce a dependency there/ will want a workaround if the data is still used.

      • The other API is for Teams high level metadata, which seems more like a good API pattern we'd want to retain as long as it's supported internally longer term. Validating and finding (or creating) docs.

4: Microsoft Build is this week

We should spend a little time learning about recent releases and roadmaps, and brainstorm if anything sounds useful for the Data Platform soon.

On the side burner

Databricks "push" pipeline for SO and knowledge handoff from Mitch

  • Chelsea started working on knowledge transfer for the new pipelines last week, as Mitch is moving into SAIL full time. This work will continue, not sure how much progress can be made this week while we handle putting the "logical"/ app code side of EdTech to bed, keeping up with Build announcements, and ordinary meeting time.

Cross team work 💪🏾💪💪🏿

ADR for Databricks -> Snowflake auth improvement

  • Chris Belay has shared an ADR for Authentication Options for Accessing Snowflake from Databricks. This will address a security limitation/ problem we have and make our authentication story more robust overall.

    • Status: ADR written, Chris will share this for review and carry on with the project after his vacation.

Restart discussions on Incremental Updates

  • Kendra will be starting discussions with other teams about how we can innovate better as well as save Databricks costs by enabling "delta"/ incremental extractions from Stack Exchange DBs
    • Feedback and comments welcome on Data Extraction for Project SAIL: A Business Case for Incremental Data Processing. (Will be using this article in the discussions.)

Restart discussions on Functional and Performance cookies

  • Kendra is researching how this data could be used for SAIL and putting together fresh context for this request

Facilitate discussions regarding Amplitude data

  • Kendra created an initial Data Ingestion request and is confirming who can speak to how the data will be segmented and who the appropriate business owner/sponsors are to make the request and work out compliance details with our Data Privacy Counsel.

Any highlights from last week you'd like to share?

  • Kendra: we have a cross-team channel for migrating Business Analytics into Snowflake now, and that's making cross-team communication easier and more fun - #bye-looker-hello-snowflake-powebi in Slack.

Summary of call with Databricks last week regarding pipeline optimization

Primary call topic: There is a concern about higher than normal Databricks spend, the call discussed opportunities to optimize and lower costs. The spike in costs historically is mostly related to reloading historical data for the trafficlogs data pipeline, however Stack's team is also concerned with future costs for Stack Exchange pipelines.

Overall call insights:

  • Mitch has already implemented a lot of the features that would reduce costs with the "reload everything" pattern, which we are currently required to use for Stack Exchange data:

    • A significant driver of costs is that we are unable to identify incremental changes from the source and are re-processing full copies of very large tables every day.

    • There aren't easy solutions for this within Databricks that we haven't already leveraged.

Call topics, summarized by PlusOne:

1. The conversation revolves around optimizing ETL pipelines, focusing on incremental loads and cluster sizing.
2. The speakers discuss using DLT autoloader, materialized views, and apply changes function within DLT for efficient data processing.
3. They explore the challenges of handling large tables and the use of row hashes for identifying changes.
4. The importance of using the latest runtime versions for performance improvements and LTS for stability is discussed.

Why is this an SO article?

This is part of an experiment in using SO Internal articles for weekly async priorities sharing, recording of recent wins, and status updates for Data Platform team members who are not currently 100% dedicated to Project SAIL. Some of the work described here may support Project SAIL but is not being carried out wholly by a SAIL pod.

By publishing this regularly in SO, we hope to:

  • Increase transparency to stakeholders and users across Stack;
  • Track team challenges and wins, both for learning and to recognize our achievements;
  • Dogfood new ways to use Teams as a product;
  • Document team priorities and activities in a way that will align with future Async MBRs.

articles.title: Principles for UI Development
articles.body:
Principles for UI Development

Detail Link
ADR Google Docs
Status Review

Context

A lack of guidance on how to evolve UIs at Stack Overflow has left teams stuck in the status quo hindering the potential for innovation modern frontend technologies bring to the table to build richer, better experiences for our customers.
This ADR aims to establish high level principles on how we build UIs at Stack Overflow which will enable teams to move fast, leveraging modern tools while avoiding the proliferation of too many technologies and standards.

Principles

  1. Use TypeScript (over JavaScript)

  2. Leverage Stacks (don’t reinvent the wheel)

  3. Use Svelte to create interactive user experiences

  4. Use Stimulus to sprinkle interactivity on static UIs

articles.title: Usage and updating the ComponentSpace.Saml2.Licensed package
articles.body:
Stack Overflow's code uses a Nuget package called ComponentSpace.Saml2.Licensed.

What is it? Why did we buy it? How do I get new versions? How do I update it?

What is it?

The product is SAML for ASP.NET Core by ComponentSpace. It is a .NET Library to handle SAML 2.0-related authentication.

Why did we buy it?

We were running our own home-grown SAML 2.0 parsing code. However, over time we ran into security issues because there are quite a few complexities when handling SAML. Since we're not in the business of writing our own Authentication code, we decided to purchase a commercial library that's supported by a company that is in the business of writing authentication code.

We have purchased their "Enterprise + Source Code" tier:

An enterprise license entitles all developers, regardless of location, to install and develop using the product. In addition, complete source code for the product is included.

(Please note that the product still has a distinct commercial license agreement that needs to be adhered to)

There is a yearly renewal that needs to go through procurement.

How do we get new versions and what to do with them?

We have a GitHub repository to keep the licensed source code/packages: https://github.com/StackEng/ComponentSpaceSAML

See the instructions in The ComponentSpaceSAML repo README.

TL;DR:

  • Subscribe to their announcement Forum
  • Email their support when you see a new update
  • Update the ComponentSpaceSAML repository with the new version (Zip File, Package, Source Code, Release Notes)
  • Update Cloudsmith (see the next section)

How do I update the package in Cloudsmith?

As a developer: Upload to nuget-3rdparty

Upload the new package to Cloudsmith into the nuget-3rdparty repository. We only care about the ComponentSpace.Saml2.Licensed nupkg and snupkg, we don't need the ComponentSpace.Saml2.Configuration.Database.Licensed package.

Click Upload -> Nuget, then upload both the nupkg and the snupkg.

Next, ping #team-devx to mirror the package into ProGet.

DevX: Sync package into ProGet

ProGet is setup with "connectors" to the nuget and nuget-software repositories in Cloudsmith. Since the ComponentSpace.Saml2.Licensed package is uploaded to nuget-3rdparty by a developer, a member of DevX needs to copy the package into the nuget repository so it can sync through ProGet. Once the package is copied into Cloudsmith's nuget repository the developer should refresh their local cache to pull the latest from Cloudsmith, as proxied through ProGet.

Update the Stack Overflow application

Now that the Package is in ProGet, you can update the Directory.Packages.props in Stack Overflow application to the new version.

articles.title: Related questions from a machine learning model
articles.body:
Ship date: May 22, 2023

Today, the CProd Consumers team graduated the first machine learning experiment to recommend Related Questions on Stack Overflow. 

What are Related Questions?

Related questions are a list of questions that appear in the sidebar on any question page you visit. They were generated using the question title and tags from Elasticsearch, a search engine that powers our embedded site search. 

Who It’s For?

✅ All users on Stack Overflow question pages

Why We Built It

According to research, discoverability is one of the top issues that users have expressed frustration. Related questions are intended to help surface relevant content in order to get users a step closer to their solution. However, we’ve heard from the Meta community the questions are not relevant.  We’ve also heard feedback that linked questions felt more relevant than related questions because they were linked by someone in an answer or comment. Given this complex problem that wouldn’t be addressable by a traditional rules-based approach, we decided to partner with the Data Platform team to leverage machine learning instead.

How does the model work? 

At its core, we leverage an embedding model which converts text into a numerical vector representing the semantic information. An embedding, a representation as vectors of decimal values, is generated for every Stack Overflow question (over 20M) using the question’s title and tags. Using semantic search, a list of similar questions is returned. Similarity is defined as the measure of distance between the vectors. Questions with a semantic similarity score closer to 1.0 indicate that the question is more relevant/similar to the original question.

User Experience

There are no visual changes to how related questions are displayed. 

Limitations

At the time of publication, there are a few limitations to the experiment:

  1. The majority of questions will be recommended by machine learning, however questions newer than February 2023 will continue to be provided by Elasticsearch because we have not implemented a way to recommend questions in near real-time.

  2. Related questions from the machine learning model are not currently updated on a schedule. We have a path forward to creating a pipeline to download questions from the model from an Azure blob storage into our on-prem database. The plan is to schedule the job to run weekly.

Next Steps

  1. Creating a mechanism to collect qualitative inline feedback directly in the interface, as many of you have requested here and here. This will allow us to incorporate human-in-the-loop feedback into the model.

  2. Expanding the signals we collect, beyond just clicks, to better measure relevance.

  3. Iterating the model using additional inputs beyond clickthrough rate, such as question body, top or accepted answer, code blocks/snippets, score, etc.

Resources

  • Shared Google drive folder

  • Jira Epic (Experiment, Graduation)

  • Experiment results

  • Meta announcement (experiment results, graduation post)

articles.title: Inside GitHub: Working with the LLMs behind GitHub Copilot
articles.body:
You can find the original source at GitHub's Blog. Below is a copy and is not original content.

Inside GitHub: Working with the LLMs behind GitHub Copilot

Developers behind GitHub Copilot discuss what it was like to work with OpenAI’s large language model and how it informed the development of Copilot as we know it today.

The first time that engineers at GitHub worked with one of OpenAI’s large language models (LLM), they were equal parts excited and astonished. Alireza Goudarzi, a senior researcher of machine learning at GitHub recounts, “As a theoretical AI researcher, my job has been to take apart deep learning models to make sense of them and how they learn, but this was the first time that a model truly astonished me.” Though the emergent behavior of the model was somewhat surprising, it was obviously powerful. Powerful enough, in fact, to lead to the creation of GitHub Copilot.

Due to the growing interest in LLMs and generative AI models, we decided to speak to the researchers and engineers at GitHub who helped build the early versions of GitHub Copilot and talk through what it was like to work with different LLMs from OpenAI, and how model improvements have helped evolve GitHub Copilot to where it is today—and beyond.

A brief history of GitHub Copilot

In June 2020, OpenAI released GPT-3, an LLM that sparked intrigue in developer communities and beyond. Over at GitHub, this got the wheels turning for a project our engineers had only talked about before: code generation.

“Every six months or so, someone would ask in our meetings, ‘Should we think about general purpose code generation,’ but the answer was always ‘No, it’s too difficult, the current models just can’t do it,’” says Albert Ziegler, a principal machine learning engineer and member of the GitHub Next research and development team.

But GPT-3 changed all that—suddenly the model was good enough to begin considering how a code generation tool might work.

“OpenAI gave us the API to play around with,” Ziegler says. “We assessed it by giving it coding-like tasks and evaluated it in two different forms.”

For the first form of evaluation, the GitHub Next team crowdsourced self-contained problems to help test the model. “The reason we don’t do this anymore is because the models just got too good,” Ziegler laughs.

In the beginning, the model could solve about half of the problems it was posed with, but soon enough, it was solving upwards of 90 percent of the problems.

This original testing method sparked the first ideas for how to harness the power of this model, and they began to conceptualize an AI-powered chatbot for developers to ask coding questions and receive immediate, runnable code snippets. “We built a prototype, but it turned out there was a better modality for this technology available,” Ziegler says. “We thought, ‘Let’s try to put this in the IDE.’”

“The moment we did that and saw how well it worked, the whole static question-and-answer modality was forgotten,” he says. “This new approach was interactive and it was useful in almost every situation.”

And with that, the development of GitHub Copilot began.

Exploring model improvements

To keep this project moving forward, GitHub returned to OpenAI to make sure that they could stay on track with the latest models. “The first model that OpenAI gave us was a Python-only model,” Ziegler remembers. “Next we were delivered a JavaScript model and a multilingual model, and it turned out that the Javascript model had particular problems that the multilingual model did not. It actually came as a surprise to us that the multilingual model could perform so well. But each time, the models were just getting better and better, which was really exciting for GitHub Copilot’s progress.”

In 2021, OpenAI released the multilingual Codex model, which was built in partnership with GitHub. This model was an offshoot of GPT-3, so its original capability was generating natural language in response to text prompts. But what set the Codex model apart was that it was trained on billions of lines of public code—so that, in addition to natural language outputs, it also produced code suggestions.

This model was open for use via an API that businesses could build on, and while this breakthrough was huge for GitHub Copilot, the team needed to work on internal model improvements to ensure that it was as accurate as possible for end users.

As the GitHub Copilot product was prepared for launch as a technical preview, the team split off into further functional teams, and the Model Improvements team became responsible for monitoring and improving GitHub Copilot’s quality through communicating with the underlying LLM. This team also set out to work on improving completion for users. Completion refers to when users accept and keep GitHub Copilot suggestions in their code, and there are several different levers that the Model Improvements team works on to increase completion, including prompt crafting and fine tuning.

An example of completion in action with GitHub Copilot.

Prompt crafting

When working with LLMs, you have to be very specific and intentional with your inputs to receive your desired output, and prompt crafting explores the art behind communicating these requests to get the optimal completion from the model.

“In very simple terms, the LLM is, at its core, just a document completion model. For training it was given partial documents and it learned how to complete them one token at a time. Therefore, the art of prompt crafting is really all about creating a ‘pseudo-document’ that will lead the model to a completion that benefits the customer,” John Berryman, a senior researcher of machine learning on the Model Improvements team explains. Since LLMs are trained on partial document completion, then if the partial document is code, then this completion capability lends itself well to code completion, which is, in its base form, exactly what GitHub Copilot does.

To better understand how the model could be applied to code completion, the team would provide the model with a file and evaluate the code completions it returned.

“Sometimes the results are ok, sometimes they are quite good, and sometimes the results seem almost magical,” Berryman says. “The secret is that we don’t just have to provide the model with the original file that the GitHub Copilot user is currently editing; instead we look for additional pieces of context inside the IDE that can hint the model towards better completions.”

He continues, “There have been several changes that helped get GitHub Copilot where it is today, but one of my favorite tricks was when we pulled similar texts in from the user’s neighboring editor tabs. That was a huge lift in our acceptance rate and characters retained.”

Generative AI and LLMs are incredibly fascinating, but Berryman still seems to be most excited about the benefit that the users are seeing from the research and engineering efforts.

“The idea here is to make sure that we make developers more productive, but the way we do that is where things start to get interesting: we can make the user more productive by incorporating the way they think about code into the algorithm itself,” Berryman says. “Where the developer might flip back and forth between tabs to reference code, we just can do that for them, and the completion is exactly what it would be if the user had taken all of the time to look that information up.”

Fine-tuning

Fine-tuning is a technique used in AI to adapt and improve a pre-trained model for a specific task or domain. The process involves taking a pre-trained model that has been trained on a large dataset and training it on a smaller, more specific dataset that is relevant to a particular use case. This enables the model to learn and adapt to the nuances of the new data, thus improving its performance on the specific task.

These larger, more sophisticated LLMs can sometimes produce outputs that aren’t necessarily helpful because it’s hard to statistically define what constitutes a “good” response. It’s also incredibly difficult to train a model like Codex that contains upwards of 170 billion parameters.

“Basically, we’re training the underlying Codex model on a user’s specific codebase to provide more focused, customized completions,” Goudarzi adds.

“Our greatest challenge right now is to consider why the user rejects or accepts a suggestion,” Goudarzi adds. “We have to consider what context, or information, that we served to the model caused the model to output something that was either helpful or not helpful. There’s no way for us to really troubleshoot in the typical engineering way, but what we can do is figure out how to ask the right questions to get the output we desire.”
